“The garden is thriving but for a few areas where the soil is too dry.”
“He could have finished the project on time but for the unexpected delays.”
“They might have won the game but for the injury of their star player.”

Vocabulary/Butt-In.title: Butt In
Vocabulary/Butt-In.content:
butt in
Definition
Word Type: phrasal verb
to interrupt a conversation or discussion or someone who is talking:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


He kept on butting in with silly comments.

Vocabulary/Butterflies-In-My-Stomach.title: Butterflies In My Stomach
Vocabulary/Butterflies-In-My-Stomach.content:
butterflies in your stomach
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
a feeling of being very nervous or frightened about something.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She had butterflies in her stomach before her first job interview.”
“He felt butterflies in his stomach as he waited to go on stage.”
“Getting up to speak in front of the large crowd gave her butterflies in her stomach.”
“Even after years of experience, he still gets butterflies in his stomach before an important presentation.”
“There were butterflies in her stomach as she awaited the results of the competition.”

Vocabulary/Butterflies-In-Your-Stomach.title: Butterflies In Your Stomach
Vocabulary/Butterflies-In-Your-Stomach.content:
butterflies in your stomach
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
a feeling of being very nervous or frightened about something.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She had butterflies in her stomach before her first job interview.”
“He felt butterflies in his stomach as he waited to go on stage.”
“Getting up to speak in front of the large crowd gave her butterflies in her stomach.”
“Even after years of experience, he still gets butterflies in his stomach before an important presentation.”
“There were butterflies in her stomach as she awaited the results of the competition.”

Vocabulary/By-Nature.title: By Nature
Vocabulary/By-Nature.content:
by nature
Definition
Word Type: phrase
used when describing someone’s character, job, etc.:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


She is, by nature, a sunny, positive kind of person.

Vocabulary/Cab-Driver.title: Cab Driver
Vocabulary/Cab-Driver.content:
cab driver
Word Type: Noun
Definition
a person who drives a taxi as a job:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


I used to be a New York City cab driver, so I know my way around.

Vocabulary/Capable.title: Capable
Vocabulary/Capable.content:
capable
Definition
Word Type: adjective
able to do things effectively and skilfully, and to achieve results:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


She’s a very capable woman/worker/judge.

Vocabulary/Carefree.title: Carefree
Vocabulary/Carefree.content:
carefree
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
Free from worries or responsibilities; relaxed and unconcerned.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The children spent a carefree afternoon playing in the park.”
“She lived a carefree lifestyle while traveling the world.”
“After finishing all her work, she felt carefree for the rest of the weekend.”
“The vacation was a perfect time for a carefree escape from daily stress.”
“He enjoyed a carefree childhood, filled with adventure and laughter.”

Vocabulary/Catch-On-To-Sth.title: Catch On To Sth
Vocabulary/Catch-On-To-Sth.content:
catch on to sth
Definition
Word Type: phrasal verb
to give someone the latest news or information about something:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Can someone catch me up on the latest developments?

Vocabulary/Catch-Up-With.title: Catch Up With
Vocabulary/Catch-Up-With.content:
catch up with
Definition
Word Type: phrasal verb
If something bad that you have done or that has been happening to you catches up with you, it begins to cause problems for you:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


His lies will catch up with him one day.

Vocabulary/Catch.title: Catch
Vocabulary/Catch.content:
catch
Word Type: verb
Definition
to take hold of something, especially something that is moving through the air:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


catch hold of He caught hold of my arm.

Vocabulary/Catchword.title: Catchword
Vocabulary/Catchword.content:
catchword
Definition
Word Type: n
a word or phrase that is popular, attention-grabbing, or frequently used, often serving as a keyword or slogan in a particular context.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The catchword of the campaign was ‘innovation’.

Vocabulary/Catchy.title: Catchy
Vocabulary/Catchy.content:
catchy
Definition
Word Type: adjective
(especially of a tune or song) pleasing and easy to remember:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


a catchy tune

Vocabulary/Change-averse.title: Change-averse
Vocabulary/Change-averse.content:
change-averse
Definition
Word Type:
someone who is change-averse is reluctant to change or adapt to new situations:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


She’s a bit change-averse - she doesn’t like change.

Vocabulary/Chaos.title: Chaos
Vocabulary/Chaos.content:
chaos
Definition
Word Type: noun
a state of total confusion with no order:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Snow and ice have caused chaos on the roads.

Vocabulary/Chaotic.title: Chaotic
Vocabulary/Chaotic.content:
chaotic
Definition
Word Type: adjective
in a state of chaos:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The house is a bit chaotic at the moment - we’ve got all these extra people staying and we’re still decorating.

Vocabulary/Cherish.title: Cherish
Vocabulary/Cherish.content:
cherish
Word Type: Verb
Definition
To hold something dear, appreciate, or take care of it with great affection or respect.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She cherishes the memories of her childhood.”
“He cherishes his time with family more than anything else.”
“They cherish the opportunity to travel the world together.”
“I cherish the moments when we can relax and enjoy a quiet evening.”
“The couple cherishes their wedding anniversary every year.”

Vocabulary/Come-To-One's-Senses.title: Come To One's Senses
Vocabulary/Come-To-One's-Senses.content:
come to one’s senses
Definition
Word Type: idiom
to begin to think in a sensible or correct way after being foolish or wrong.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


He finally came to his senses and gave up his plans to quit his job and become an artist.

Vocabulary/Come-Up-With-Sth.title: Come Up With Sth
Vocabulary/Come-Up-With-Sth.content:
come up with sth
Definition
Word Type: phrasal verb
to suggest or think of an idea or plan:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


She’s come up with some amazing scheme to double her income.

Vocabulary/Commence.title: Commence
Vocabulary/Commence.content:
commence
Definition
Word Type: v
to begin something.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Shall we let the meeting commence

Vocabulary/Commonplace.title: Commonplace
Vocabulary/Commonplace.content:
commonplace
Word Type: Adjective, Noun
Definition

Ordinary and not special; something that happens frequently or is widely accepted.
A common or ordinary thing, idea, or occurrence.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“In modern cities, the use of smartphones has become commonplace.”
“The idea of working remotely is no longer a commonplace practice.”
“It was commonplace to see people riding bicycles in the park during the summer.”
“The once-rare technology is now a commonplace in homes across the world.”
“His views on politics are not new; they are quite commonplace.”

Vocabulary/Compliment.title: Compliment
Vocabulary/Compliment.content:
compliment
Definition
Word Type: noun
a remark that expresses approval, admiration, or respect:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


He complained that his husband never paid him any compliments anymore.

Vocabulary/Concentration.title: Concentration
Vocabulary/Concentration.content:
concentration
Definition
Word Type: noun
the ability to think carefully about something you are doing and nothing else:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The noise outside made concentration difficult.

Vocabulary/Confront.title: Confront
Vocabulary/Confront.content:
confront
Word Type: Verb
Definition
To face or deal with something or someone, often in a challenging or direct way.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She had to confront her fear of public speaking before giving the presentation.”
“The manager decided to confront the issue with the team’s performance head-on.”
“He was forced to confront the reality of the situation after the accident.”
“It’s important to confront your problems instead of avoiding them.”
“They will need to confront the challenges of the new project soon.”

Vocabulary/Confusion.title: Confusion
Vocabulary/Confusion.content:
confusion
Word Type: Noun
Definition
A state of being unclear or uncertain, often caused by a lack of understanding or organization.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“There was a lot of confusion about the new schedule.”
“The sudden change in plans caused some confusion among the team members.”
“His vague explanation led to confusion during the meeting.”
“After hearing both sides of the argument, she was in complete confusion.”
“The complex instructions led to confusion in assembling the furniture.”

Vocabulary/Conspicuous.title: Conspicuous
Vocabulary/Conspicuous.content:
conspicuous
Definition
Word Type: adjective
very noticeable or attracting attention, often in a way that is not wanted:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


In China, her blonde hair was conspicuous.

Vocabulary/Contest.title: Contest
Vocabulary/Contest.content:
contest
Word Type: Noun, Verb
Definition

A competition or event where people compete against each other for a prize or title.
To take part in or compete in a contest.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Noun: “She won the singing contest at school.”
Noun: “The cooking contest attracted dozens of talented chefs.”
Verb: “He decided to contest the election results, claiming they were unfair.”
Verb: “They will contest the championship game next week.”

Vocabulary/Continent.title: Continent
Vocabulary/Continent.content:
continent
Word Type: Noun, Adjective
Definition

one of the seven large land masses on the earth’s surface, surrounded, or mainly surrounded, by sea and usually consisting of various countries.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The North American continent.”
“The continents of Asia and Africa.”

Vocabulary/Cornerstone.title: Cornerstone
Vocabulary/Cornerstone.content:
cornerstone
Word Type: Noun
Definition
A fundamental or essential element, often regarded as the foundation of something.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“Trust is the cornerstone of any successful relationship.”
“The new building’s cornerstone was laid during a ceremony last week.”
“Education is the cornerstone of a prosperous society.”
“His integrity was the cornerstone of his career in law.”
“The company’s commitment to innovation is the cornerstone of its success.”

Vocabulary/Creativity.title: Creativity
Vocabulary/Creativity.content:
creativity
Definition
Word Type: noun
the ability to produce or use original and unusual ideas:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Too many rules might deaden creativity.

Vocabulary/Creep-Up-On-Behind-Someone.title: Creep Up On-Behind Someone
Vocabulary/Creep-Up-On-Behind-Someone.content:
creep up on/behind someone
Definition
Word Type: phrasalverb
If a feeling or state creeps up on you, you start to experience it so gradually that you do not realize it.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


It was only after I turned 60 that old age began to creep up on me.

Vocabulary/Creep-Up-On.title: Creep Up On
Vocabulary/Creep-Up-On.content:
creep up on
Word Type: Phrasal Verb
Definition
to surprise someone and move closer to them without being seen or heard.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The noise from the approaching storm crept up on them as they sat in the garden.”
“The realization of how much work was left to do crept up on her in the last hour.”
“I didn’t hear him come in; he must have crept up behind me.”
“The feeling of anxiety began to creep up on him as the deadline approached.”
“The fog slowly crept up on the town, making it hard to see.”

Vocabulary/Critic-criticism.title: Critic-criticism
Vocabulary/Critic-criticism.content:
critic/criticism
Definition
Word Type:
Definition not found


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Critic.title: Critic
Vocabulary/Critic.content:
critic
Word Type: noun
Definition
someone who says that they do not approve of someone or something:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Her critics say she is leading the party to disaster.

Vocabulary/Criticism.title: Criticism
Vocabulary/Criticism.content:
criticism
Definition
Word Type: noun
the act of saying that something or someone is bad or a comment that says what is bad about it:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


criticism of There has been a lot of criticism of the decision.

Vocabulary/Curiosity.title: Curiosity
Vocabulary/Curiosity.content:
curiosity
Word Type: Noun
Definition
A strong desire to learn or know more about something or someone.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“Her curiosity led her to explore different cultures around the world.”
“The detective’s curiosity helped solve the mysterious case.”
“Children often have an insatiable curiosity about how things work.”
“His curiosity about space and the stars grew after visiting the planetarium.”
“The scientist’s curiosity drove her to make groundbreaking discoveries in genetics.”

Vocabulary/Debate.title: Debate
Vocabulary/Debate.content:
debate
Word Type: Noun, Verb
Definition

A formal discussion or argument about a particular issue, where opposing viewpoints are presented.
To engage in a formal discussion or argument about a topic.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The debate over climate change has been ongoing for years.”
“They had a debate about the best course of action for the project.”
“The candidates will debate the issues on live television tonight.”
“The team debated the merits of the proposed strategy before making a decision.”
“The university hosted a debate on freedom of speech and its limits.”

Vocabulary/Deem.title: Deem
Vocabulary/Deem.content:
deem
Definition
Word Type: verb
to consider or judge something in a particular way:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


[ + obj + noun/adj  ] The area has now been deemed safe.

Vocabulary/Delve-Into-Something.title: Delve Into Something
Vocabulary/Delve-Into-Something.content:
delve into something
Definition
Word Type: phrasalverb
to examine, investigate, or explore a subject or topic deeply and thoroughly, often to uncover details or gain a better understanding.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


She loves to delve into ancient myths and legends for inspiration.

Vocabulary/Desperate.title: Desperate
Vocabulary/Desperate.content:
desperate
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
Feeling a hopeless sense of urgency, often due to difficult circumstances or an overwhelming desire for something.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She was desperate to find a job after months of searching.”
“The desperate situation called for immediate action.”
“He made a desperate attempt to win her back, but she had already moved on.”
“The team was desperate to score in the final minutes of the game.”
“After the accident, he felt desperate for any help he could get.”

Vocabulary/Despise.title: Despise
Vocabulary/Despise.content:
despise
Word Type: Verb
Definition
To feel a strong dislike or contempt for someone or something.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She despises people who are dishonest.”
“He despises waking up early in the morning.”
“They despise the way the company treats its employees.”
“I absolutely despise the taste of coffee.”
“He despises being told what to do.”

Vocabulary/Diligence.title: Diligence
Vocabulary/Diligence.content:
diligence
Definition
Word Type:
the quality of working carefully and with a lot of effort:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


She hoped that her diligence would be noticed at work.

Vocabulary/Dilligence.title: Dilligence
Vocabulary/Dilligence.content:
dilligence
Word Type:
Definition
Definition not found


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Direct-Something-At-Someone-s.title: Direct Something At Someone-something
Vocabulary/Direct-Something-At-Someone-s.content:
direct something at someone/something
Word Type: Verb Phrase
Definition
To aim or focus a message, action, or object towards a specific person or thing.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The teacher decided to direct her feedback at the students who struggled the most with the assignment.

Vocabulary/Disability.title: Disability
Vocabulary/Disability.content:
disability
Definition
Word Type: noun
an illness, injury, or condition that makes it difficult for someone to do some things that other people do, and that is usually permanent or lasts for a long time:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


a physical/learning disability

Vocabulary/Disable.title: Disable
Vocabulary/Disable.content:
disable
Word Type: verb
Definition
to cause someone to have an illness, injury, or condition that makes it difficult for them to do the things that other people do:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


She was disabled in the accident.

Vocabulary/Disappear.title: Disappear
Vocabulary/Disappear.content:
disappear
Word Type: verb
Definition
If people or things disappear, they go somewhere where they cannot be seen or found:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The search was called off for the sailors who disappeared in the storm.

Vocabulary/Disappearance.title: Disappearance
Vocabulary/Disappearance.content:
disappearance
Word Type: noun
Definition
the fact of someone or something disappearing:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


A man was being questioned in connection with her disappearance.

Vocabulary/Discharge-From.title: Discharge From
Vocabulary/Discharge-From.content:
discharge from
Definition
Word Type: noun
an order from a court that allows someone who is legally bankrupt to stop owing money for particular debts:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Although a bankrupt’s name may be removed from the register within a year after discharge from bankruptcy, credit reference agencies may keep records for six to ten years.

Vocabulary/Discharge.title: Discharge
Vocabulary/Discharge.content:
discharge
Definition
Word Type: verb
to allow someone officially to leave somewhere, especially a hospital or a law court:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


be discharged from Patients were discharged from the hospital because the beds were needed by other people.

Vocabulary/Discontent.title: Discontent
Vocabulary/Discontent.content:
discontent
Definition
Word Type: noun
a feeling of wanting better treatment or an improved situation:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


discontent among Discontent among junior ranks was rapidly spreading.

Vocabulary/Discontentment.title: Discontentment
Vocabulary/Discontentment.content:
discontentment
Definition
Word Type: noun
a feeling of wanting better treatment or an improved situation:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


discontent among Discontent among junior ranks was rapidly spreading.

Vocabulary/Dismiss.title: Dismiss
Vocabulary/Dismiss.content:
dismiss
Word Type: Verb
Definition

To send someone away or allow them to leave.
To reject or refuse to consider something as unimportant or unworthy of attention.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The teacher dismissed the students early for the holiday break.”
“He dismissed her ideas without even listening to them.”
“The manager dismissed the complaint, claiming it wasn’t a serious issue.”
“She dismissed the invitation because she had other plans.”
“They dismissed the rumors as mere gossip.”

Vocabulary/Dispassionate.title: Dispassionate
Vocabulary/Dispassionate.content:
dispassionate
Definition
Word Type: adjective
able to think clearly or make good decisions because of not being influenced by emotions:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


In all the media hysteria, there was one journalist whose comments were clear-sighted and dispassionate.

Vocabulary/Dispassionately.title: Dispassionately
Vocabulary/Dispassionately.content:
dispassionately
Definition
Word Type: adverb
in a way that is not influenced by emotions:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


He thought about his actions quite coldly and dispassionately.

Vocabulary/Dispersal.title: Dispersal
Vocabulary/Dispersal.content:
dispersal
Definition
Word Type: noun
the action of spreading across or moving away over a large area, or of making people or things do this:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


dispersal of We have seen the violent dispersal of crowds of protesters.

Vocabulary/Disperse.title: Disperse
Vocabulary/Disperse.content:
disperse
Definition
Word Type: verb
to spread across or move away over a large area, or to make something do this:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


When the rain came down the crowds started to disperse.

Vocabulary/Distrain.title: Distrain
Vocabulary/Distrain.content:
distrain
Definition
Word Type: verb
to take and sell property from someone who owes you money in order to pay back their debt:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Under the law, landlords have a legal right to distrain goods from a defaulting tenant in lieu of rent arrears.

Vocabulary/Do-Wonder.title: Do Wonder
Vocabulary/Do-Wonder.content:
do wonder
Word Type: idiom
Definition
to cause improvements or have a very good effect:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


That new guy is great – he’s done wonders for the company.

Vocabulary/Domain.title: Domain
Vocabulary/Domain.content:
domain
Word Type: Noun
Definition
an area of knowledge, activity, or control.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“Mathematics is her primary domain of expertise.”
“The website operates in the education domain, providing resources for students.”
“The forest became part of the king’s domain after the conquest.”
“In computer science, a domain refers to a specific part of a network, like a website address.”
“Art and design are outside his domain, but he’s eager to learn.”

Vocabulary/Doubt.title: Doubt
Vocabulary/Doubt.content:
doubt
Word Type: Noun, Verb
Definition

A feeling of uncertainty or lack of conviction.
To be uncertain about something or to question its truth.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She had doubt about the success of the project.”
“There’s no doubt that he will win the competition.”
“I doubt whether they will arrive on time.”
“He was filled with doubt after hearing the contradictory statements.”
“Don’t doubt yourself; you’re capable of achieving great things.”

Vocabulary/Driven-By.title: Driven By
Vocabulary/Driven-By.content:
driven by
Definition
Word Type: Phrase
Motivated or propelled by a particular factor, desire, or ambition.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Her success in the competition was driven by her passion for music and relentless practice.

Vocabulary/Drop-Off.title: Drop Off
Vocabulary/Drop-Off.content:
drop off
Word Type: Phrasal Verb
Definition

To take someone or something to a particular place and leave them/it there.
To decrease or decline gradually.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“Can you drop off the package at the post office on your way home?”
“I will drop off my friend at the airport before heading to work.”
“Sales of the product began to drop off after the initial excitement.”
“The quality of the project seemed to drop off after the first few weeks.”

Vocabulary/Each-To-Their-Own.title: Each To Their Own
Vocabulary/Each-To-Their-Own.content:
each to their own
Definition
Word Type: phrase
used to say that everyone likes different things:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


You actually like modern jazz, do you? Each to their own.

Vocabulary/Echo.title: Echo
Vocabulary/Echo.content:
echo
Word Type: Noun, Verb
Definition

an echo is a sound that is reflected off a surface and heard again.
to echo means to repeat or reflect a sound, feeling, or idea.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Noun: “The echo of her voice filled the empty hall.”
Verb: “His words echoed through the canyon.”
Verb: “Her feelings of excitement echoed in the crowd’s cheers.”
Noun: “We could hear the echo of the church bells from miles away.”
Verb: “The speech echoed the sentiments of unity and strength.”

Vocabulary/Economic.title: Economic
Vocabulary/Economic.content:
economic
Definition
Word Type: adjective
relating to trade, industry, or money:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The country has been in a very poor economic state ever since the decline of its two major industries.

Vocabulary/Economical.title: Economical
Vocabulary/Economical.content:
economical
Definition
Word Type: adjective
using as little of something as possible; wasting nothing or very little:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


economical with People were urged to be economical with water as a drought was declared.

Vocabulary/Economically.title: Economically
Vocabulary/Economically.content:
economically
Definition
Word Type: adverb
using little money, time, etc.:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


As a student she lived very economically, rarely going out and buying very few clothes.

Vocabulary/Economics.title: Economics
Vocabulary/Economics.content:
economics
Definition
Word Type: noun
the way in which trade, industry, or money is organized, or the study of this:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Their ideas sound fine in principle, but they haven’t worked out the economics behind the policies.

Vocabulary/Economy.title: Economy
Vocabulary/Economy.content:
economy
Definition
Word Type: noun
the system of trade and industry by which the wealth of a country is made and used:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


global economy Technology companies are driving the global economy.

Vocabulary/Effortlessly.title: Effortlessly
Vocabulary/Effortlessly.content:
effortlessly
Definition
Word Type: adverb
in a way that is effortless (= seeming not to need any effort):


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


She runs so effortlessly, as if it’s the easiest thing in the world.

Vocabulary/Ego.title: Ego
Vocabulary/Ego.content:
Ego
Word Type: Noun
Definition
A person’s sense of self-esteem or self-importance; in psychology, the part of the mind that mediates between the conscious and unconscious, responsible for reality-testing and a sense of personal identity.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“His ego was bruised when he didn’t get the promotion he expected.”
“She has a big ego, always wanting to be the center of attention.”
“In difficult situations, it’s important to put your ego aside and focus on teamwork.”
“The psychologist explained how the ego works to balance our desires and reality.”
“Criticism can sometimes hurt the ego, but it helps us grow.”

Vocabulary/Embrace.title: Embrace
Vocabulary/Embrace.content:
embrace
Word Type: Verb
Definition

To hold someone closely in your arms, especially as a sign of affection.
To accept or support something willingly and enthusiastically.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She embraced her friend tightly after not seeing her for years.”
“He embraced the idea of moving to a new city for a fresh start.”
“The couple embraced each other as they celebrated their wedding day.”
“The community embraced the new changes to the neighborhood park.”
“She was ready to embrace the challenges that came with the new job.”

Vocabulary/Empathy.title: Empathy
Vocabulary/Empathy.content:
empathy
Word Type: Noun
Definition
The ability to understand and share the feelings of another person.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“Her empathy for the homeless led her to volunteer at a shelter.”
“He showed great empathy when his friend was going through a difficult time.”
“Doctors need a lot of empathy to understand their patients’ pain and concerns.”
“She expressed empathy by listening attentively to his struggles.”
“The team’s empathy towards each other made them work well together.”

Vocabulary/End-up.title: End up
Vocabulary/End-up.content:
end up
Word Type: Phrasal Verb
Definition
To eventually reach a particular place, state, or situation, often unexpectedly or after a process.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“They didn’t plan to go out, but they ended up at the movies.”
“After a long discussion, we ended up agreeing on the same solution.”
“He started studying medicine but ended up becoming a lawyer.”
“We ended up staying longer than expected because the weather was so nice.”
“Despite the initial setbacks, the project ended up being a great success.”

Vocabulary/Endless.title: Endless
Vocabulary/Endless.content:
endless
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
Something that seems to have no end, or feels as though it continues without limit.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“They had an endless supply of food at the party.”
“The meeting seemed endless, lasting for hours.”
“She was tired of the endless questions about her career.”
“The endless road stretched out before us in the desert.”
“There was an endless series of events planned for the weekend.”

Vocabulary/Enrich.title: Enrich
Vocabulary/Enrich.content:
enrich
Definition
Word Type: verb
to improve the quality of something by adding something else:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Fertilizer helps to enrich the soil.

Vocabulary/Entrain.title: Entrain
Vocabulary/Entrain.content:
entrain
Definition
Word Type: verb
to get on a train:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


On 2nd May we entrained for Dieppe.

Vocabulary/Envision.title: Envision
Vocabulary/Envision.content:
envision
Word Type: Verb
Definition
To imagine or visualize something, especially something that will happen in the future.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She envisioned a bright future for her startup company.”
“He could never envision himself living in a big city.”
“The artist envisioned a masterpiece before starting the painting.”
“They envisioned a world where technology and nature coexist harmoniously.”
“He envisioned the project completed ahead of schedule.”

Vocabulary/Estimate.title: Estimate
Vocabulary/Estimate.content:
estimate
Definition
Word Type: verb
to guess or calculate the cost, size, value, etc. of something:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Government sources estimate a long-term 50 percent increase in rail fares.

Vocabulary/Et.title: Et
Vocabulary/Et.content:
et
Definition
Word Type: verb
to obtain, buy, or earn something:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


He went to the shop to get some milk.

Vocabulary/Everlasting.title: Everlasting
Vocabulary/Everlasting.content:
everlasting
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
Lasting forever or for a very long time; eternal.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“They promised everlasting love to each other during their wedding vows.”
“The monument was built to honor the everlasting spirit of the community.”
“Some stories seem to have everlasting appeal, passed down through generations.”
“The everlasting beauty of the landscape left the tourists in awe.”
“Their friendship was an everlasting bond that could not be broken.”

Vocabulary/Exceed.title: Exceed
Vocabulary/Exceed.content:
exceed
Word Type: Verb
Definition
To go beyond a limit or surpass expectations.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“Her performance in the competition exceeded everyone’s expectations.”
“The amount of work required to finish the project exceeded his initial estimate.”
“The company’s profits this year exceeded all predictions.”
“He has exceeded the speed limit by 10 miles per hour.”
“The demand for the new product exceeded supply, causing shortages.”

Vocabulary/Extracurricular.title: Extracurricular
Vocabulary/Extracurricular.content:
extracurricular
Definition
Word Type: adjective
An extracurricular activity or subject is not part of the usual school or college course:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


extracurricular activity Parents could also get financial help with the cost of extracurricular activities at school.

Vocabulary/Extrovert.title: Extrovert
Vocabulary/Extrovert.content:
extrovert
Definition
Word Type: noun
an energetic person who enjoys being with other people:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Most sales people are extroverts.

Vocabulary/Exxagerate.title: Exxagerate
Vocabulary/Exxagerate.content:
exxagerate
Definition
Word Type:
to make something seem larger, more important, better, or worse than it really is:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


I’m not exaggerating - it was the worst meal I’ve ever eaten in my life.

Vocabulary/Eye-Opening.title: Eye-Opening
Vocabulary/Eye-Opening.content:
eye-opening
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
Causing a person to learn or realize something surprising or new, often in a way that changes their perspective.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The documentary was truly eye-opening, revealing the impact of climate change on wildlife.”
“Her eye-opening experience traveling abroad changed her views on cultural diversity.”
“The eye-opening book made me rethink my approach to education.”
“It was an eye-opening conversation that taught me a lot about leadership.”
“The eye-opening workshop gave employees valuable insights into improving their productivity.”

Vocabulary/Facilitate.title: Facilitate
Vocabulary/Facilitate.content:
facilitate
Definition
Word Type: verb
to make something possible or easier:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The new ramp will facilitate the entry of wheelchairs.

Vocabulary/Fall-Into.title: Fall Into
Vocabulary/Fall-Into.content:
fall into
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
To accidentally or gradually begin to do something or become involved in a particular situation or category.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“He didn’t plan to become a teacher, but he fell into it after helping out at a school.”
“The conversation fell into a discussion about politics.”
“She fell into the habit of exercising every morning.”
“After years of hard work, he finally fell into a position of leadership.”
“The company fell into financial troubles after a poor investment.”

Vocabulary/Familiarize.title: Familiarize
Vocabulary/Familiarize.content:
familiarize
Word Type: Verb
Definition
To make someone or something familiar with something by learning about it or getting used to it.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The guide will familiarize you with the museum’s exhibits before the tour starts.”
“Before starting the new job, take some time to familiarize yourself with the company’s policies.”
“She spent a few hours trying to familiarize herself with the software.”
“You should familiarize yourself with the new rules before the meeting.”
“The teacher helped the students familiarize themselves with the textbook.”

Vocabulary/Fantasy.title: Fantasy
Vocabulary/Fantasy.content:
fantasy
Word Type: Noun
Definition
An imagined experience or idea, especially one that is unrealistic or not based on real life.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The movie is a fantasy adventure set in a magical world.”
“She has always dreamed of living in a fantasy land, far from reality.”
“His idea of becoming a famous rock star was just a fantasy.”
“The book explores themes of fantasy and escapism, transporting readers to different worlds.”
“While it’s fun to imagine a fantasy world, we must focus on real-world challenges.”

Vocabulary/Feed-An-Ego.title: Feed An Ego
Vocabulary/Feed-An-Ego.content:
Feed an Ego
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
To praise or flatter someone excessively, often to the point of making them feel overly important or self-centered.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“By constantly telling him how great he is, you’re just feeding his ego.”
“She didn’t need anyone to feed her ego, but the compliments kept coming.”
“He loves it when people feed his ego, especially when he wins a game.”
“Her manager was always feeding her ego, which made her feel even more confident.”
“They always feed his ego, making him believe he can do no wrong.”

Vocabulary/Feigning-Ignorance.title: Feigning Ignorance
Vocabulary/Feigning-Ignorance.content:
Feigning Ignorance
Word Type: Phrase
Definition
The act of pretending not to know or understand something, often to avoid responsibility or to deceive others.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Despite his extensive knowledge of the project, he was feigning ignorance when questioned by his supervisor about the missing reports.

Vocabulary/Fetish.title: Fetish
Vocabulary/Fetish.content:
fetish
Definition
Word Type: noun
a sexual interest in an object or a part of the body other than the sexual organs:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


a rubber/foot fetish

Vocabulary/Fill-something-with-something.title: Fill something with something
Vocabulary/Fill-something-with-something.content:
fill something with something
Word Type: Phrase/Verb
Definition
To put a substance or material into a container, space, or area until it is full or occupied.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She filled the cup with coffee before handing it to him.”
“They filled the room with balloons for the party.”
“The chef filled the pan with vegetables before cooking them.”
“He filled the box with books to send to the charity.”
“The air was filled with the sound of birds chirping.”

Vocabulary/Financially-Independent.title: Financially Independent
Vocabulary/Financially-Independent.content:
Financially Independent
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
Not reliant on others for financial support; having sufficient income or resources to support oneself without assistance.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


After years of saving and investing wisely, she finally felt financially independent enough to start her own business.

Vocabulary/Flexible.title: Flexible
Vocabulary/Flexible.content:
flexible
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
Able to change or be changed easily to suit different conditions or situations.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She has a flexible work schedule, which allows her to manage both work and personal commitments.”
“The team adopted a flexible approach to problem-solving, adjusting strategies as needed.”
“The flexible material can be bent and stretched without breaking.”
“Being flexible in your plans can help you adapt to unexpected changes.”
“The manager was praised for her flexible attitude in handling various tasks.”

Vocabulary/Fond-of.title: Fond of
Vocabulary/Fond-of.content:
Fond of
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
To like or have a strong affection for someone or something.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She’s very fond of reading historical novels in her free time.”
“I’m not fond of spicy food, so I usually avoid it.”
“He’s particularly fond of animals and volunteers at the shelter.”
“They are fond of traveling and have visited many countries.”
“My grandmother is fond of gardening and has a beautiful flower garden.”

Vocabulary/Fool-Around.title: Fool Around
Vocabulary/Fool-Around.content:
fool around
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
To behave in a silly or playful way, often wasting time or avoiding serious tasks.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“Stop fooling around and focus on your homework!”
“They spent the whole afternoon fooling around instead of working on the project.”
“We were just fooling around at the park, enjoying the sunny weather.”
“He tends to fool around during meetings, which can be distracting.”
“Don’t fool around with that tool; it might be dangerous.”

Vocabulary/For-Your-Someone'S-Own-Good.title: For Your-Someone'S Own Good
Vocabulary/For-Your-Someone'S-Own-Good.content:
for your/someone’s own good
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
To do something with the intention of benefiting the person, even if they may not realize it or agree at the time.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“I know you’re upset, but I’m making you take a break for your own good.”
“She was strict with her children for their own good, wanting them to develop good habits.”
“He told her to stop working so much, for her own good, because it was affecting her health.”
“The doctor suggested she cut back on sugar for her own good.”
“Although it felt uncomfortable, the tough feedback was for his own good.”

Vocabulary/Force-Upon.title: Force Upon
Vocabulary/Force-Upon.content:
Force upon
Word Type: Verb Phrase
Definition
To impose something on someone, often in a way that is unwelcome or not asked for.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“He tried to force his opinions upon everyone in the meeting.”
“I don’t want to force my help upon you, but let me know if you need it.”
“The new policy was forced upon the employees without any discussion.”
“She felt like the rules were being forced upon her, even though she didn’t agree with them.”
“It’s unfair to force your decisions upon others without considering their opinions.”

Vocabulary/Foster.title: Foster
Vocabulary/Foster.content:
foster
Word Type: Verb
Definition
To encourage the development or growth of something, or to care for someone, especially a child, in a supportive or nurturing way.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The teacher worked hard to foster a love of reading in her students.”
“They hope to foster a sense of community through the new program.”
“He decided to foster a child after hearing about the need for adoptive parents.”
“The organization aims to foster understanding between different cultures.”
“By volunteering, she wanted to foster positive change in the community.”

Vocabulary/Generate.title: Generate
Vocabulary/Generate.content:
generate
Definition
Word Type: verb
to cause something to exist:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


generate interest/excitement Her latest film has generated a lot of interest/excitement.

Vocabulary/Generous.title: Generous
Vocabulary/Generous.content:
generous
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
Showing a willingness to give more of something, such as time, money, or kindness, than is strictly necessary or expected.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She was generous with her time, always volunteering to help others.”
“He gave a generous donation to the charity to support the cause.”
“The host was generous in offering us plenty of food and drinks.”
“They showed a generous spirit by inviting everyone to the celebration.”
“His generous nature made him beloved by all who knew him.”

Vocabulary/Geographic.title: Geographic
Vocabulary/Geographic.content:
geographic
Definition
Word Type: adjective
relating to geography, or to the geography of a particular area or place:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


a geographic region

Vocabulary/Geographical.title: Geographical
Vocabulary/Geographical.content:
geographical
Definition
Word Type: adjective
relating to geography, or to the geography of a particular area or place:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


a geographical region

Vocabulary/Geographically.title: Geographically
Vocabulary/Geographically.content:
geographically
Definition
Word Type: adverb
in a way that relates to geography (= the study of places, especially their physical position and features), or to the geography of a particular area or place:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Venezuela has the advantage of being geographically close to the United States.

Vocabulary/Geography.title: Geography
Vocabulary/Geography.content:
geography
Definition
Word Type: noun
the study of the systems and processes involved in the world’s weather, mountains, seas, lakes, etc. and of the ways in which countries and people organize life within an area


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


the geography of Australia

Vocabulary/Get-Along.title: Get Along
Vocabulary/Get-Along.content:
get along
Definition
Word Type: phr v
If two or more people get along, they like each other and are friendly to each other:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


get along with I don’t really get along with my sister’s husband.

Vocabulary/Get-Away-With-Something.title: Get Away With Something
Vocabulary/Get-Away-With-Something.content:
get away with something
Word Type: Phrasal Verb
Definition
to succeed in avoiding punishment for something:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“He managed to get away with cheating on the exam.”
“She thought she could get away with skipping work, but her boss found out.”
“They tried to get away with not paying their taxes, but the authorities caught them.”
“He always gets away with being late because his boss likes him.”
“The thief thought he could get away with stealing, but the police were quick to catch him.”

Vocabulary/Get-Away-With.title: Get Away With
Vocabulary/Get-Away-With.content:
get away with something
Word Type: Phrasal Verb
Definition
to succeed in avoiding punishment for something:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“He managed to get away with cheating on the exam.”
“She thought she could get away with skipping work, but her boss found out.”
“They tried to get away with not paying their taxes, but the authorities caught them.”
“He always gets away with being late because his boss likes him.”
“The thief thought he could get away with stealing, but the police were quick to catch him.”

Vocabulary/Get-Credit-For.title: Get Credit For
Vocabulary/Get-Credit-For.content:
get credit for
Definition
Word Type: collocation
to be given praise, approval, or honour for something you have done:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


I’m not getting credit for what I’m doing.

Vocabulary/Get-Off.title: Get Off
Vocabulary/Get-Off.content:
get off
Definition
Word Type: phr v
to leave a place, usually in order to start a journey:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


If we can get off by seven o’clock, the roads will be clearer.

Vocabulary/Get-Something-In-One's-Favor.title: Get Something In One's Favor
Vocabulary/Get-Something-In-One's-Favor.content:
get something in one’s favor
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
To achieve a situation where someone has an advantage or positive outcome, often due to persuasion or circumstances.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She worked hard to get the situation in her favor before the meeting.”
“He tried to get the negotiations in his favor by offering a better deal.”
“By presenting the data clearly, she was able to get the argument in her favor.”
“The team managed to get the game in their favor after a tough first half.”
“He used his charm to get the decision in his favor during the discussion.”

Vocabulary/Get-caught.title: Get caught
Vocabulary/Get-caught.content:
Get caught
Word Type: Phrasal Verb
Definition
To be discovered or apprehended, usually in the act of doing something wrong or illegal.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“He tried to sneak out of the house but got caught by his parents.”
“She got caught cheating on the test and had to face the consequences.”
“The thief was trying to escape, but he got caught by the police.”
“I didn’t want to tell anyone, but I got caught talking about it.”
“They got caught in the rain without umbrellas and were soaked.”

Vocabulary/Get.title: Get
Vocabulary/Get.content:
get
Word Type: verb
Definition
to obtain, buy, or earn something:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


He went to the shop to get some milk.

Vocabulary/Getting-Away-With-It.title: Getting Away With It
Vocabulary/Getting-Away-With-It.content:
Get away with something
Definition
Phrasal Verb
To escape blame or punishment when you do something wrong, or to avoid harm or criticism for something you did.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


If I thought I could get away with it, I wouldn’t pay my taxes at all.
By jumping over the barriers, he got away without paying for a ticket.
Everyone thinks he’s guilty of the robbery, but it looks like he’s going to get away with it.
It’s time they put a stop to his bad behaviour. He’s been getting away with it for too long.
She’s determined that her students will not get away with plagiarism.
That’s such an old trick. I can’t believe he gets away with it.

Vocabulary/Giggle.title: Giggle
Vocabulary/Giggle.content:
giggle
Word Type: Verb / Noun
Definition

To laugh in a light, silly, or nervous way.
A silly or nervous laugh.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She couldn’t help but giggle at the funny joke.”
“The children were giggleing during the magic show.”
“His giggle was so contagious that everyone in the room started laughing.”
“She tried to suppress her giggle during the serious meeting.”
“They shared a quiet giggle when they saw the surprise.”

Vocabulary/Give-Something-A-Go-thought.title: Give Something A Go-thought
Vocabulary/Give-Something-A-Go-thought.content:
give something a go/thought
Word Type:
Definition
to attempt something for the first time


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


I’ve been interested in growing my own food for a while, and since I’ve got an allotment this season, I thought I’d give it a go.

Vocabulary/Give-Something-A-Thought.title: Give Something A Thought
Vocabulary/Give-Something-A-Thought.content:
give something a go/thought
Definition
Word Type:
to attempt something for the first time:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


I’ve been interested in growing my own food for a while, and since I’ve got an allotment this season, I thought I’d give it a go

Vocabulary/Glitch.title: Glitch
Vocabulary/Glitch.content:
glitch
Word Type: Noun
Definition
A small, often temporary problem or malfunction, especially in a system or machine.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The computer froze because of a minor glitch in the software.”
“There was a slight glitch during the live broadcast, but it was quickly fixed.”
“The website experienced a glitch, causing it to go offline for a few minutes.”
“They solved the glitch in the system that was causing delays.”
“Despite the glitch in the presentation, the event went smoothly.”

Vocabulary/Go-South.title: Go South
Vocabulary/Go-South.content:
go south
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
to become much worse.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“Everything was going well with the project, but then it went south when we missed the deadline.”
“The negotiations went south after the disagreement over the terms.”
“Our plans for the weekend went south when the weather turned bad.”
“The company’s profits went south due to poor management.”
“The meeting started off well but went south when the team couldn’t agree on the budget.”

Vocabulary/Granted.title: Granted
Vocabulary/Granted.content:
granted
Word Type: conjunction
Definition
used to admit that something is true, before saying something else about it:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


granted that Granted that the story’s true, there’s not a lot you can do about it.

Vocabulary/Grateful.title: Grateful
Vocabulary/Grateful.content:
grateful
Definition
Word Type: adjective
showing or expressing thanks, especially to another person:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


grateful (to someone) for something I’m so grateful (to you) for all that you’ve done.

Vocabulary/Gratefully.title: Gratefully
Vocabulary/Gratefully.content:
gratefully
Definition
Word Type: adverb
in a grateful way:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


She smiled at me gratefully.

Vocabulary/Gratification.title: Gratification
Vocabulary/Gratification.content:
gratification
Definition
Word Type: noun
pleasure or satisfaction, or something which provides this:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


sexual gratification

Vocabulary/Gratitude.title: Gratitude
Vocabulary/Gratitude.content:
gratitude
Definition
Word Type: noun
the feeling or quality of being grateful:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


deep/eternal gratitude

Vocabulary/Gratuitous.title: Gratuitous
Vocabulary/Gratuitous.content:
gratuitous
Definition
Word Type: adjective
(of something such as bad behaviour) not necessary, or with no cause:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


gratuitous sex/violence A lot of viewers complained that there was too much gratuitous sex and violence in the film.

Vocabulary/Gratuitously.title: Gratuitously
Vocabulary/Gratuitously.content:
gratuitously
Definition
Word Type: adverb
(of something bad) in a way that is not necessary, or that is without cause:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


gratuitously violent

Vocabulary/Guarantee.title: Guarantee
Vocabulary/Guarantee.content:
guarantee
Word Type: Noun, Verb
Definition

A formal promise or assurance, typically written, that something will happen or is true.
To provide a formal assurance or promise that something will happen or is true.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The company offers a guarantee on all of its products for one year.”
“He gave his guarantee that the project would be completed on time.”
“I can guarantee that you’ll love this movie.”
“The warranty guarantees that the appliance will be repaired free of charge within the first two years.”
“The guarantee covers any defects in the product for up to five years.”

Vocabulary/Hang-Out.title: Hang Out
Vocabulary/Hang-Out.content:
hang out
Word Type: Phrasal Verb
Definition
To spend time relaxing or socializing, usually in a casual or informal way.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“We usually hang out at the park after school.”
“On weekends, I like to hang out with my friends at the mall.”
“They hung out at the café for hours, chatting and enjoying the weather.”
“Do you want to hang out this weekend?”
“After the concert, we decided to hang out at a nearby diner.”

Vocabulary/Hassle.title: Hassle
Vocabulary/Hassle.content:
hassle
Definition
Word Type: noun
(a situation causing) difficulty or trouble:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


I can’t face the hassle of moving again.

Vocabulary/Have-A-Room-For-Sth.title: Have A Room For Sth
Vocabulary/Have-A-Room-For-Sth.content:
have a room for sth
Word Type:
Definition
Definition not found


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Headbang.title: Headbang
Vocabulary/Headbang.content:
headbang
Word Type: Verb
Definition
To rhythmically shake or move one’s head, typically in time with heavy music, especially rock or metal, often as a form of expression or enjoyment.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The crowd began to headbang enthusiastically as the band played their most popular song.

Vocabulary/Headmaster.title: Headmaster
Vocabulary/Headmaster.content:
headmaster
Word Type: Noun
Definition
The principal or leader of a school, especially in the UK or some other countries.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The headmaster announced the school’s new policy during the assembly.”
“The headmaster of the school has been in charge for over ten years.”
“Parents met with the headmaster to discuss their child’s progress.”
“The headmaster praised the students for their hard work and dedication.”
“After the incident, the headmaster took immediate action to improve safety.”

Vocabulary/Helpless.title: Helpless
Vocabulary/Helpless.content:
helpless
Definition
Word Type: adjective
unable to do anything to help yourself or anyone else:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


a helpless two-day-old baby

Vocabulary/Helplessly.title: Helplessly
Vocabulary/Helplessly.content:
helplessly
Definition
Word Type: adverb
in a way that is helpless (= unable to do anything to help yourself or anyone else):


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Unable to swim, he watched helplessly as the child struggled desperately in the water.

Vocabulary/Helplessness.title: Helplessness
Vocabulary/Helplessness.content:
helplessness
Definition
Word Type: noun
the feeling or state of being unable to do anything to help yourself or anyone else:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Doing something for others can stem feelings of helplessness.

Vocabulary/Highly-Likely.title: Highly Likely
Vocabulary/Highly-Likely.content:
highly likely
Word Type: adjective phrase
Definition
Very probable or expected to occur; having a strong chance of happening.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


It is highly likely that the event will be canceled due to the severe weather forecast.

Vocabulary/Hit-The-Hay.title: Hit The Hay
Vocabulary/Hit-The-Hay.content:
hit the hay
Definition
Word Type: idiom
to go to bed in order to sleep:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


I have a busy day tomorrow, so I think I’ll hit the sack.

Vocabulary/Hustle.title: Hustle
Vocabulary/Hustle.content:
hustle
Definition
Word Type: verb
to make someone move quickly by pushing or pulling them along:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


After giving his speech, Johnson was hustled out of the hall by bodyguards.

Vocabulary/Hustsle.title: Hustsle
Vocabulary/Hustsle.content:
hustsle
Word Type:
Definition
Definition not found


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Identity.title: Identity
Vocabulary/Identity.content:
identity
Word Type: Noun
Definition
The characteristics, qualities, or beliefs that make a person or group different from others; the fact of being who or what a person or thing is.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“His identity was kept secret for years to protect his safety.”
“Cultural identity plays a big role in shaping a person’s worldview.”
“She struggled to find her identity after moving to a new country.”
“The company’s identity is reflected in its logo and brand messaging.”
“Your identity is shaped by your experiences and personal choices.”

Vocabulary/Ignite.title: Ignite
Vocabulary/Ignite.content:
ignite
Word Type: Verb
Definition
To start a fire, to cause something to burn, or to provoke a strong emotion or reaction.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The spark from the wire ignited the dry grass, starting a wildfire.”
“Her speech ignited a wave of support for the new charity.”
“The idea of moving abroad ignited his sense of adventure.”
“The news of the promotion ignited his excitement.”
“The protest ignited a national conversation about workers’ rights.”

Vocabulary/Ignorance.title: Ignorance
Vocabulary/Ignorance.content:
ignorance
Definition
Word Type: noun
lack of knowledge, understanding, or information about something:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


ignorance about Public ignorance about the disease is still a cause for concern.

Vocabulary/Ignorant.title: Ignorant
Vocabulary/Ignorant.content:
ignorant
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
Lacking knowledge or awareness in general, or about a particular subject or fact.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“He was ignorant of the rules, so he accidentally made a mistake.”
“Her ignorant comments about the topic showed that she hadn’t done any research.”
“They were ignorant of the cultural differences, which led to misunderstandings.”
“It’s important to avoid being ignorant about others’ feelings.”
“He seemed ignorant of the consequences of his actions.”

Vocabulary/Illegible.title: Illegible
Vocabulary/Illegible.content:
illegible
Definition
Word Type: adjective
(of writing or print) impossible or almost impossible to read because of being very untidy or not clear:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


His writing is almost illegible.

Vocabulary/Illegibly.title: Illegibly
Vocabulary/Illegibly.content:
illegibly
Definition
Word Type: adverb
in a way that is impossible or almost impossible to read because the writing or print is very untidy or not clear:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The reports were illegibly written in pencil.

Vocabulary/Imponderable.title: Imponderable
Vocabulary/Imponderable.content:
imponderable
Definition
Word Type: noun
something that cannot be guessed or calculated because it is completely unknown:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


There are too many imponderables to make an accurate forecast.

Vocabulary/Improvident.title: Improvident
Vocabulary/Improvident.content:
improvident
Definition
Word Type: adjective
not planning carefully for the future, especially by spending money in a way that is unwise


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/In-The-Blink-Of-An-Eye.title: In The Blink Of An Eye
Vocabulary/In-The-Blink-Of-An-Eye.content:
in the blink of an eye
Definition
Word Type: idiom
extremely quickly:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


In the blink of an eye, he was gone.

Vocabulary/In-The-Mean-Time.title: In The Mean Time
Vocabulary/In-The-Mean-Time.content:
in the mean time
Definition
Word Type: idiom
while waiting for something else to happen:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


In the meantime, I’ll just get on with my work.

Vocabulary/In-The-Name-Of-Someone-Someth.title: In The Name Of Someone-Something
Vocabulary/In-The-Name-Of-Someone-Someth.content:
in the name of someone/something
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
To do something for the purpose of honoring or representing someone or something, often with the implication of justification or authority.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“They built the new school in the name of community development.”
“The charity was founded in the name of helping underprivileged children.”
“The soldiers fought in the name of freedom and justice.”
“He made the decision in the name of the company’s best interests.”
“The project was launched in the name of environmental conservation.”

Vocabulary/Inability.title: Inability
Vocabulary/Inability.content:
inability
Definition
Word Type: noun
lack of ability to do something:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


[ + to infinitive ] Inability to use a computer is a serious disadvantage when you are applying for jobs.

Vocabulary/Incalculable.title: Incalculable
Vocabulary/Incalculable.content:
incalculable
Definition
Word Type: adjective
extremely large and therefore unable to be measured:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The ecological consequences of a nuclear war are incalculable.

Vocabulary/Indifferent.title: Indifferent
Vocabulary/Indifferent.content:
indifferent
Definition
Word Type: adjective
not thinking about or interested in someone or something:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


indifferent (to) Why don’t you vote - how can you be so indifferent (to what is going on)?

Vocabulary/Indifferently.title: Indifferently
Vocabulary/Indifferently.content:
indifferently
Definition
Word Type: adverb
in a way that shows you are not thinking about or interested in someone or something:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


She shrugged indifferently.

Vocabulary/Indispensable.title: Indispensable
Vocabulary/Indispensable.content:
indispensable
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
Absolutely necessary or essential; something that cannot be done without.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“Her knowledge and experience are indispensable to the success of the project.”
“Good communication skills are indispensable in any professional job.”
“The internet has become indispensable for work and leisure activities.”
“A reliable transportation system is indispensable in a busy city.”
“Honesty is an indispensable trait in any friendship.”

Vocabulary/Inevitable.title: Inevitable
Vocabulary/Inevitable.content:
inevitable
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
Certain to happen and impossible to avoid.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The end of the project felt inevitable after so many setbacks.”
“As technology advances, some changes in the job market are inevitable.”
“The storm’s arrival was inevitable, given the weather patterns.”
“He knew the decision to leave was inevitable, despite his reluctance.”
“It’s inevitable that new trends will emerge as society evolves.”

Vocabulary/Inexpressible.title: Inexpressible
Vocabulary/Inexpressible.content:
inexpressible
Definition
Word Type: adjective
An inexpressible feeling is too strong to be described:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The news filled him with inexpressible delight/joy/horror/pain.

Vocabulary/Influence.title: Influence
Vocabulary/Influence.content:
influence
Word Type: Noun, Verb
Definition

The power to have an effect on people, events, or things.
To affect or change someone or something in an indirect way.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“Her positive influence helped motivate the entire team.”
“The media can influence public opinion on many important issues.”
“His influence in the company grew after he secured the major deal.”
“She used her charm to influence the decision-making process.”
“Many believe that climate change will influence global policies in the coming years.”

Vocabulary/Ingratitude.title: Ingratitude
Vocabulary/Ingratitude.content:
ingratitude
Definition
Word Type: noun
the fact that someone is not grateful for something


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Innocent.title: Innocent
Vocabulary/Innocent.content:
innocent
Word Type: Adjective
Definition

Not guilty of a crime or offense.
Free from moral wrong or corruption; pure.
Not causing harm or offense; harmless.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The defendant was found innocent of all charges.”
“She gave me an innocent smile, unaware of the situation.”
“His questions seemed innocent, but they made me feel uncomfortable.”
“The innocent child was unaware of the dangers around him.”
“The innocent plant is harmless and can be safely kept in any room.”

Vocabulary/Input.title: Input
Vocabulary/Input.content:
input
Word Type: noun
Definition
something such as energy, money, or information that is put into a system, organization, or machine so that it can operate:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


input into I didn’t have much input into the project (= the help I gave was small).

Vocabulary/Inquiry.title: Inquiry
Vocabulary/Inquiry.content:
inquiry
Word Type: Noun
Definition
The act of asking for information or investigation into a particular subject or issue.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The police opened an inquiry into the missing person case.”
“She made an inquiry about the job opening at the company.”
“The professor conducted an inquiry into the effects of climate change.”
“He sent an inquiry to the customer service department about his refund.”
“The company’s financial inquiry revealed some discrepancies in the reports.”

Vocabulary/Insight.title: Insight
Vocabulary/Insight.content:
insight
Definition
Word Type: noun
(the ability to have) a clear, deep, and sometimes sudden understanding of a complicated problem or situation:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


insight into It was an interesting book, full of fascinating insights into human relationships.

Vocabulary/Intangible.title: Intangible
Vocabulary/Intangible.content:
intangible
Definition
Word Type: adjective
impossible to touch, to describe exactly, or to give an exact value:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


She has that intangible quality which you might call charisma.

Vocabulary/Interfere.title: Interfere
Vocabulary/Interfere.content:
interfere
Definition
Word Type: verb
to involve yourself in a situation when your involvement is not wanted or is not helpful:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


It’s their problem and I’m not going to interfere.

Vocabulary/Interference.title: Interference
Vocabulary/Interference.content:
interference
Definition
Word Type: noun
an occasion when someone tries to interfere in a situation:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


She seems to regard any advice or help from me as interference.

Vocabulary/Interpretation.title: Interpretation
Vocabulary/Interpretation.content:
interpretation
Definition
Word Type: noun
an explanation or opinion of what something means:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The dispute is based on two widely differing interpretations of the law.

Vocabulary/Interpretive.title: Interpretive
Vocabulary/Interpretive.content:
interpretive
Definition
Word Type: adjective
related to explaining or understanding the meaning of something:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


an interpretive display/centre

Vocabulary/Intervene-In.title: Intervene In
Vocabulary/Intervene-In.content:
intervene in
Definition
Word Type:
to try to stop or change something that is happening:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The government intervened in the dispute between the two companies.

Vocabulary/Intervention.title: Intervention
Vocabulary/Intervention.content:
intervention
Word Type: Noun
Definition
The act of intervening, especially to help or change a situation.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The teacher’s intervention helped the students understand the difficult topic.”
“The government’s intervention was necessary to prevent a financial crisis.”
“Family intervention was required to help him overcome his addiction.”
“The United Nations’ intervention brought peace to the war-torn region.”
“The doctor’s intervention saved her life during the emergency.”

Vocabulary/Intolerant.title: Intolerant
Vocabulary/Intolerant.content:
intolerant
Definition
Word Type: adjective
refusing to accept particular ideas, beliefs, behaviour, especially because they are different from your own, or refusing to accept people who are different from you:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


intolerant of In the later years of his rule he became increasingly intolerant of dissent.

Vocabulary/Intransitive.title: Intransitive
Vocabulary/Intransitive.content:
intransitive
Definition
Word Type: adjective
(of a verb) having or needing no object:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


In the sentence

Vocabulary/Intransitively.title: Intransitively
Vocabulary/Intransitively.content:
intransitively
Definition
Word Type: adverb
(of a verb) in an intransitive way (= not having or needing an object ):


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Many verbs can be used either intransitively or transitively, including “eat”, “help”, “walk”, etc.

Vocabulary/Intransitivity.title: Intransitivity
Vocabulary/Intransitivity.content:
intransitivity
Word Type:
Definition
Definition not found


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Introvert.title: Introvert
Vocabulary/Introvert.content:
introvert
Definition
Word Type: noun
someone who is shy, quiet, and prefers to spend time alone rather than often being with other people


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Ironically-Enough.title: Ironically Enough
Vocabulary/Ironically-Enough.content:
Ironically enough
Word Type: Adverbial Phrase
Definition
Used to highlight an ironic or unexpected situation, where the outcome is contrary to what one would expect.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“Ironically enough, he didn’t like the movie, even though it was his favorite director’s work.”
“Ironically enough, the person who was most afraid of the interview ended up getting the job.”
“Ironically enough, after all that preparation, we missed the bus.”
“Ironically enough, she’s the one who suggested the idea that led to the problem.”
“Ironically enough, the worst weather came after we made all the travel plans.”

Vocabulary/Irresponsible.title: Irresponsible
Vocabulary/Irresponsible.content:
irresponsible
Word Type: adjective
Definition
not thinking enough or not worrying about the possible results of what you do:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


[ + to infinitive ] It would be irresponsible to ignore these warnings.

Vocabulary/Irresponsibly.title: Irresponsibly
Vocabulary/Irresponsibly.content:
irresponsibly
Word Type: adverb
Definition
in a way that shows that you are not thinking or worrying enough about the possible results of what you do:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


It’s unlike you to behave so irresponsibly.

Vocabulary/Irritated.title: Irritated
Vocabulary/Irritated.content:
irritated
Definition
Word Type: adjective
annoyed:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


I began to get increasingly irritated by/at her questions.

Vocabulary/Jam-To-Music.title: Jam To Music
Vocabulary/Jam-To-Music.content:
jam to music
Definition
Word Type:
to play music on a radio or tape player:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


I’m jamming to music while I’m working.

Vocabulary/Jam-To.title: Jam To
Vocabulary/Jam-To.content:
jam to
Word Type: Phrasal Verb
Definition
