To play music loudly and enthusiastically, often in an informal setting, or to dance and enjoy music energetically.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“We decided to jam to our favorite songs all night long.”
“The band started to jam to the rhythm, and the crowd went wild.”
“Everyone gathered at the party and began to jam to some classic rock hits.”
“They love to jam to jazz music on weekends.”
“At the concert, people couldn’t resist but jam to the upbeat tempo.”

Vocabulary/Jot-Down.title: Jot Down
Vocabulary/Jot-Down.content:
jot down
Word Type: Phrasal Verb
Definition
To quickly write something down, usually a note or brief information.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She asked me to jot down her phone number before she left.”
“During the meeting, I had to jot down a few important points.”
“I’ll jot down the address so I don’t forget it.”
“Can you jot down the details of the event so we can review them later?”
“He quickly jotted down the recipe before his grandmother could forget it.”

Vocabulary/Jot-Sth-Down.title: Jot Sth Down
Vocabulary/Jot-Sth-Down.content:
jot sth down
Definition
Word Type: phrasal verb
to write something quickly on a piece of paper so that you remember it:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


I carry a notebook so that I can jot down any ideas.

Vocabulary/Just.title: Just
Vocabulary/Just.content:
just
Definition
Word Type: adverb
now, very soon, or very recently:


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Keep-It-To-Oneself.title: Keep It To Oneself
Vocabulary/Keep-It-To-Oneself.content:
keep it to oneself
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
To not share or reveal something, especially a secret or personal information, to others.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“He decided to keep it to himself and not tell anyone about the surprise party.”
“When asked about the rumors, she chose to keep it to herself.”
“I’ll keep it to myself if you don’t want anyone to know.”
“He prefers to keep things to himself rather than share his thoughts with others.”
“Instead of gossiping, she chose to keep it to herself and mind her own business.”

Vocabulary/Keep-This-Between-Us.title: Keep This Between Us
Vocabulary/Keep-This-Between-Us.content:
keep this between us
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
To not share a piece of information with anyone else; to keep something private or confidential.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“I’m going to tell you a secret, but please keep this between us.”
“She asked him to keep this between us and not tell anyone else about her plans.”
“I’ll let you in on my idea, but you have to keep this between us for now.”
“He promised to keep this between us, knowing how sensitive the topic was.”
“Let’s keep this between us until we’re ready to announce it publicly.”

Vocabulary/Keep-Up.title: Keep Up
Vocabulary/Keep-Up.content:
keep up
Word Type: Phrasal Verb
Definition

To continue at the same pace or level, often with others.
To maintain or stay informed about something.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She had to run faster to keep up with the rest of the group.”
“He struggled to keep up with the demands of his new job.”
“It’s hard to keep up with all the new technology in the industry.”
“They worked together to keep up with the project deadline.”
“I can’t keep up with the news; it changes too quickly.”

Vocabulary/Kind.title: Kind
Vocabulary/Kind.content:
kind
Definition
Word Type: adjective
generous, helpful, and thinking about other people’s feelings:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


She’s a very kind and thoughtful person.

Vocabulary/Kindly.title: Kindly
Vocabulary/Kindly.content:
kindly
Definition
Word Type: adverb
in a kind way:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Stella has very kindly offered to help out with the food for the party.

Vocabulary/L.title: L
Vocabulary/L.content:
l
Definition
Word Type: adjective
not thinking enough or not worrying about the possible results of what you do:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


[ + to infinitive ] It would be irresponsible to ignore these warnings.

Vocabulary/Lance.title: Lance
Vocabulary/Lance.content:
lance
Definition
Word Type: noun
a long, thin pole with a sharp point that soldiers used in the past as a weapon when riding horses


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


She had a boil lanced at the doctor’s this morning.

Vocabulary/Lead-somebody-astray.title: Lead somebody astray
Vocabulary/Lead-somebody-astray.content:
Lead somebody astray
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
To cause someone to make a mistake, behave badly, or move away from the correct path or belief.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“Bad company can easily lead someone astray during their teenage years.”
“She was led astray by false promises of fame and success.”
“The guide’s poor directions led them astray, and they got lost in the forest.”
“Misleading information on social media often leads people astray from the truth.”
“He regrets letting his emotions lead him astray during the argument.”

Vocabulary/Leal.title: Leal
Vocabulary/Leal.content:
leal
Word Type:
Definition
Definition not found


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Leave-With-Little-Room-For.title: Leave With Little Room For
Vocabulary/Leave-With-Little-Room-For.content:
Leave with Little Room for
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
To provide very few options, possibilities, or opportunities for something else.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The strict rules leave little room for creativity in the design process.”
“The new policy leaves little room for exceptions.”
“His explanation was so clear that it left little room for further questions.”
“The budget cuts leave little room for any extra expenses.”
“Her answer was firm and left little room for negotiation.”

Vocabulary/Legitimacy.title: Legitimacy
Vocabulary/Legitimacy.content:
legitimacy
Word Type: Noun
Definition
The quality of being legitimate, valid, or accepted according to law, rules, or standards.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The legitimacy of the election results was questioned by several political parties.”
“He challenged the legitimacy of the business practices in the industry.”
“The court examined the legitimacy of the will before distributing the estate.”
“The legitimacy of her claim was confirmed by legal experts.”
“There were concerns about the legitimacy of the research methods used in the study.”

Vocabulary/Lesion.title: Lesion
Vocabulary/Lesion.content:
lesion
Word Type: noun
Definition
an injury to a person’s body or to an organ inside their body:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


skin/brain lesions

Vocabulary/Less.title: Less
Vocabulary/Less.content:
less
Word Type: determiner
Definition
a smaller amount (of), or to a smaller degree:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


We must try to spend less money.

Vocabulary/Lest.title: Lest
Vocabulary/Lest.content:
lest
Word Type: conjunction
Definition
in order to prevent any possibility that something will happen:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


They were afraid to complain about the noise lest they annoyed the neighbours.

Vocabulary/Ley.title: Ley
Vocabulary/Ley.content:
ley
Word Type: noun
Definition
an imaginary line between some important places such as hills, believed to be where there were very old paths. Ley lines are sometimes thought to have special powers.


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Like-The-Back-Of-My-Hand.title: Like The Back Of My Hand
Vocabulary/Like-The-Back-Of-My-Hand.content:
know something like the back of your hand
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
To know something very well and be extremely familiar with it.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“He knows the city like the back of his hand, so he can guide us anywhere.”
“She knows how to use the software like the back of her hand, which makes her an expert in the office.”
“I’ve worked here for years, and I know this system like the back of my hand.”
“After living in the neighborhood for so long, she knows every street like the back of her hand.”
“The chef knows every recipe like the back of his hand, which is why his meals are so perfect.”

Vocabulary/Like-The-Back-Of-One's-Hand.title: Like The Back Of One's Hand
Vocabulary/Like-The-Back-Of-One's-Hand.content:
like the back of one’s hand
Word Type: idiom
Definition
To have an intimate and thorough knowledge of something; to know something very well.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


She knows the city like the back of her hand, so she can give you the best directions.

Vocabulary/Literal.title: Literal
Vocabulary/Literal.content:
literal
Definition
Word Type: adjective
The literal meaning of a word is its original, basic meaning:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The literal meaning of

Vocabulary/Literally.title: Literally
Vocabulary/Literally.content:
literally
Word Type: adverb
Definition
using the real or original meaning of a word or phrase:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


They were responsible for literally millions of deaths.

Vocabulary/Live.title: Live
Vocabulary/Live.content:
live
Definition
Word Type: verb
(to continue) to be alive or have life:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


He only lived a few days after the accident.

Vocabulary/Long-To-Do-Something.title: Long To Do Something
Vocabulary/Long-To-Do-Something.content:
long to do something
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
To have a strong desire or yearning to do something.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She longs to travel around the world and experience new cultures.”
“He longed to see his family after being away for so long.”
“I long to learn more about ancient history.”
“After years of hard work, he longed to relax and take a break.”
“They longed to be together again after the long separation.”

Vocabulary/Look-Back.title: Look Back
Vocabulary/Look-Back.content:
look back
Word Type: Phrasal Verb
Definition
To think about or reflect on the past.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She likes to look back on her childhood memories.”
“Don’t look back; focus on moving forward.”
“When I look back at that moment, I realize how much I’ve learned.”
“They often look back at their early years as a time of great change.”
“He tried not to look back at his past mistakes, focusing on the future instead.”

Vocabulary/Lose-Count-Of-Sth.title: Lose Count Of Sth
Vocabulary/Lose-Count-Of-Sth.content:
lose count of sth
Definition
Word Type: idiom
to not be able to remember a total:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


I’ve lost count of how many times she’s been late for work this month.

Vocabulary/Lose.title: Lose
Vocabulary/Lose.content:
lose
Definition
Word Type: verb
to no longer have something because you do not know where it is:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


I’ve lost my ticket.

Vocabulary/Low-maintenance.title: Low-maintenance
Vocabulary/Low-maintenance.content:
Low-maintenance
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
Describing something or someone that requires little care, effort, or attention to maintain.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She’s a low-maintenance friend who doesn’t expect a lot of attention.”
“The plant is perfect for beginners because it’s low-maintenance and only needs watering once a week.”
“Their new car is low-maintenance, saving them time and money on repairs.”
“I prefer low-maintenance furniture that doesn’t need constant cleaning.”
“He likes to live in a low-maintenance home, where everything is simple and easy to care for.”

Vocabulary/M--.title: M--
Vocabulary/M--.content:
m//
Definition
Word Type:
Definition not found


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Make-Difference.title: Make Difference
Vocabulary/Make-Difference.content:
made a difference
Word Type: Idiomatic Phrase
Definition
To have a significant impact or effect on something, making a positive change.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“Her volunteer work really makes a difference in the community.”
“Even small acts of kindness can make a difference in someone’s day.”
“The new policy will make a difference in reducing pollution.”
“He believes that education can make a difference in people’s lives.”
“Their donation helped make a difference for many families in need.”

Vocabulary/Make-For.title: Make For
Vocabulary/Make-For.content:
make for
Definition
Word Type: phrasal verb
to go in the direction of a place or thing:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


They made for the centre of town.

Vocabulary/Make-Out.title: Make Out
Vocabulary/Make-Out.content:
make out
Definition
Word Type: phrasal verb
to see, hear, or understand something or someone with difficulty:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The numbers are too small - I can’t make them out at all.

Vocabulary/Make-Up-Sth.title: Make Up Sth
Vocabulary/Make-Up-Sth.content:
make up sth
Definition
Word Type: phrasal verb
to invent something, such as an excuse or a story, often in order to deceive:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


make up an excuse I made up an excuse about having to look after the kids.

Vocabulary/Make-Up.title: Make Up
Vocabulary/Make-Up.content:
make up
Word Type: Phrasal Verb
Definition
To invent or create something, often a story or excuse, that is not true or is imagined.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“He made up an excuse for being late to the meeting.”
“She made up a story about meeting a celebrity at the airport.”
“They had to make up a new plan after the original one fell through.”
“The children love to make up stories before bedtime.”
“Don’t make up things to avoid taking responsibility for your actions.”

Vocabulary/Make.title: Make
Vocabulary/Make.content:
make
Definition
Word Type: verb
to produce something, often using a particular substance or material:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Do you want me to make some coffee?

Vocabulary/Manufacturer.title: Manufacturer
Vocabulary/Manufacturer.content:
manufacturer
Definition
Word Type: noun
a company that produces goods in large numbers:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Germany is a major manufacturer of motor cars.

Vocabulary/Mass.title: Mass
Vocabulary/Mass.content:
mass
Definition
Word Type: adjective
having an effect on or involving a large number of people or forming a large amount:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


weapons of mass destruction

Vocabulary/Massage.title: Massage
Vocabulary/Massage.content:
massage
Definition
Word Type: verb
to rub and press someone’s body with regular repeated movements, in order to relax them or to reduce stiffness or pain in the joints (= places where two bones are connected) or muscles:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Would you massage my shoulders?

Vocabulary/Massive.title: Massive
Vocabulary/Massive.content:
massive
Definition
Word Type: adjective
very large in size, amount, or number:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


They have a massive house.

Vocabulary/Memorable.title: Memorable
Vocabulary/Memorable.content:
memorable
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
Worth remembering or easily remembered, especially because it is special or unusual.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The wedding was a memorable occasion, filled with love and laughter.”
“Her memorable speech inspired everyone in the room.”
“The sunset over the ocean was one of the most memorable sights I’ve ever seen.”
“It was a memorable experience to meet my favorite author in person.”
“The memorable concert left the audience in awe.”

Vocabulary/Merely.title: Merely
Vocabulary/Merely.content:
merely
Word Type: Adverb
Definition
Used to emphasize that something is only what is specified, with no more than that; just or simply.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“He merely suggested a different approach, not a solution.”
“The mistake was merely a misunderstanding.”
“She wasn’t upset; she was merely tired.”
“The project is merely in the planning stages right now.”
“He is merely a beginner and has much to learn.”

Vocabulary/Miracle.title: Miracle
Vocabulary/Miracle.content:
miracle
Word Type: Noun
Definition
An extraordinary and unexplainable event or action that causes wonder, often attributed to divine intervention.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“It was a miracle that she survived the car crash without a scratch.”
“The recovery of the patient was considered a miracle by the doctors.”
“Many believe that the birth of a child is a miracle.”
“Winning the lottery was a miracle for him and his family.”
“The sudden end to the long drought was seen as a miracle by the farmers.”

Vocabulary/Misfortunate.title: Misfortunate
Vocabulary/Misfortunate.content:
misfortunate
Word Type:
Definition
Definition not found


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Misfortune.title: Misfortune
Vocabulary/Misfortune.content:
misfortune
Definition
Word Type: a
bad luck, or an unfortunate event:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


It’s a real misfortune that he’s lost his job.

Vocabulary/Miss-Out-On.title: Miss Out On
Vocabulary/Miss-Out-On.content:
miss out on
Word Type: Phrasal Verb
Definition
To fail to include someone or something, or to not take part in something.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“I think you missed out on an important detail in the report.”
“She was upset because she felt missed out of the team activities.”
“I don’t want to miss out on the concert tickets, so I’ll buy them now.”
“He was disappointed to realize he had missed out on the opportunity.”
“If you don’t act fast, you might miss out on the special offer.”

Vocabulary/Missing-Out-On.title: Missing Out On
Vocabulary/Missing-Out-On.content:
missing out
Word Type: Phrasal Verb
Definition
To fail to include someone or something, or to not take part in something.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“I think you missed out on an important detail in the report.”
“She was upset because she felt missed out of the team activities.”
“I don’t want to miss out on the concert tickets, so I’ll buy them now.”
“He was disappointed to realize he had missed out on the opportunity.”
“If you don’t act fast, you might miss out on the special offer.”

Vocabulary/Monetary.title: Monetary
Vocabulary/Monetary.content:
monetary
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
Relating to money or finance.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The company faced monetary difficulties during the economic downturn.”
“He received a monetary reward for his hard work and dedication.”
“The government implemented monetary policies to control inflation.”
“They decided to make a monetary donation to the charity.”
“She was concerned about the monetary implications of buying a new house.”

Vocabulary/Mother-Tongue.title: Mother Tongue
Vocabulary/Mother-Tongue.content:
mother tongue
Definition
Word Type: Noun
the first language that you learn when you are a baby, rather than a language learned at school or as an adult


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Motivate.title: Motivate
Vocabulary/Motivate.content:
motivate
Word Type: Verb
Definition
To make someone want to do something, especially by encouraging or inspiring them.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“Her teacher’s praise helped motivate her to work harder in school.”
“The coach gave a speech to motivate the team before the game.”
“He was motivated by a desire to help others succeed.”
“The company introduced rewards to motivate employees to improve productivity.”
“Seeing her friend’s success motivated her to start her own business.”

Vocabulary/Move-On.title: Move On
Vocabulary/Move-On.content:
move on
Word Type: Phrasal Verb
Definition

To stop thinking or talking about something and begin focusing on other things.
To leave one situation and start something new, especially after a difficult or emotional experience.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“After the breakup, it took her a while, but she finally decided to move on.”
“He didn’t get the job, but he’s ready to move on and apply elsewhere.”
“They argued for hours, but eventually, they had to move on to other topics.”
“After the disappointment, it’s time to move on and focus on the next challenge.”
“She found it hard to move on after losing her childhood pet.”

Vocabulary/Much-Of-A-Fight.title: Much Of A Fight
Vocabulary/Much-Of-A-Fight.content:
Much of a Fight
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
To be a significant or tough struggle, often implying that something was harder or more challenging than expected.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She didn’t think it would be much of a fight, but the competition was fierce.”
“We didn’t expect much of a fight when we tried to get the deal approved, but it took longer than we thought.”
“The debate over the new policy turned out to be much of a fight, with strong opposing opinions.”
“He thought winning the race would be easy, but it was much of a fight to the finish line.”
“The negotiation seemed like it wouldn’t be much of a fight, but the opposing team was very difficult to deal with.”

Vocabulary/Naive.title: Naive
Vocabulary/Naive.content:
naive
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
Describes someone who is innocent, inexperienced, or overly trusting, often in a way that leads to them being easily deceived.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She was naive to believe that everyone at work had her best interests at heart.”
“His naive approach to investing led him to make poor financial decisions.”
“At a young age, he was naive about the complexities of adult life.”
“Her naive optimism made her believe that the project would succeed without challenges.”
“The naive tourist fell for the scam in the busy market.”

Vocabulary/Narcissism.title: Narcissism
Vocabulary/Narcissism.content:
narcissism
Definition
Word Type: noun
too much interest in and admiration for your own physical appearance and/or your own abilities


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Necessary.title: Necessary
Vocabulary/Necessary.content:
necessary
Definition
Word Type: adjective
needed in order to achieve a particular result:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


He lacks the necessary skills for the job.

Vocabulary/Nonexistent.title: Nonexistent
Vocabulary/Nonexistent.content:
nonexistent
Definition
Word Type: adjective
completely absent:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Crime is virtually nonexistent around here.

Vocabulary/Noninterference.title: Noninterference
Vocabulary/Noninterference.content:
noninterference
Definition
Word Type: noun
a policy of not trying to stop something or not involving yourself in something that another person, country, etc. is trying to do:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The Pact included an agreement of mutual non-interference among its member states.

Vocabulary/Obligation.title: Obligation
Vocabulary/Obligation.content:
obligation
Word Type: Noun
Definition
A duty or responsibility to do something, often because of legal, moral, or social reasons.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She felt an obligation to help her friend move into the new apartment.”
“As a citizen, it is our obligation to vote in elections.”
“The company has an obligation to ensure the safety of its employees.”
“He was under no obligation to attend the meeting, but he decided to go.”
“Parents have an obligation to provide for their children’s needs.”

Vocabulary/Obsequious.title: Obsequious
Vocabulary/Obsequious.content:
obsequious
Definition
Word Type: adjective
too eager to praise or obey someone:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


She is embarrassingly obsequious to anyone in authority.

Vocabulary/Obsequiously.title: Obsequiously
Vocabulary/Obsequiously.content:
obsequiously
Definition
Word Type: adverb
in a way that is too eager to praise or obey someone:


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Off-The-Beaten-Track.title: Off The Beaten Track
Vocabulary/Off-The-Beaten-Track.content:
off the beaten track
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
To be in a place that is far from any main roads or outside of the usual or traditional path or area, often suggesting something unusual or unconventional.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“They decided to go off the beaten track and explore the remote villages in the mountains.”
“The restaurant is a bit off the beaten track, but the food is worth the detour.”
“The hike took us off the beaten track, away from the crowded tourist spots.”
“She loves visiting off the beaten track destinations that most people don’t know about.”
“Their wedding ceremony was held in an off the beaten track location, deep in the forest.”

Vocabulary/Off-The-Chart.title: Off The Chart
Vocabulary/Off-The-Chart.content:
off the chart
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
Used to describe something that is extremely high or exceeds the usual limits, often referring to performance, success, or a measurement.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“Her performance in the competition was off the charts, earning her first place.”
“The concert was off the charts, with fans praising the energy and sound.”
“The sales numbers for this product are off the charts, surpassing all expectations.”
“The team’s effort in the final match was off the charts, securing their victory.”
“His creativity is off the charts, producing unique and impressive designs.”

Vocabulary/Off-The-Charts.title: Off The Charts
Vocabulary/Off-The-Charts.content:
off the charts
Definition
Word Type: idiom
at a very high level.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


His blood pressure was off the charts.

Vocabulary/On-(An)-Impulse.title: On (An) Impulse
Vocabulary/On-(An)-Impulse.content:
on (an) impulse
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
To do something suddenly and without planning, often driven by a spontaneous desire or emotion.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She bought the dress on impulse while shopping with her friends.”
“He quit his job on impulse after a frustrating meeting with his boss.”
“They decided to go on a trip to the beach on an impulse, without any preparation.”
“I didn’t plan to eat out, but we went to the restaurant on impulse.”
“He called her on impulse, just to see how she was doing.”

Vocabulary/On-End.title: On End
Vocabulary/On-End.content:
on end
Definition
Word Type: idiom
continuously:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


She practices the violin for hours on end.

Vocabulary/On-Impulse.title: On Impulse
Vocabulary/On-Impulse.content:
on (an) impulse
Definition
phrase
because you suddenly want to, although you haven’t planned to.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                

She bought the dress on impulse, even though she didn’t need it.

Vocabulary/On-The-Brink-Of.title: On The Brink Of
Vocabulary/On-The-Brink-Of.content:
On the Brink of
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
To be very close to experiencing or achieving something, often something significant or extreme.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The company was on the brink of bankruptcy before the new CEO took over.”
“The patient was on the brink of recovery after weeks of treatment.”
“She was on the brink of tears after hearing the good news.”
“The nation was on the brink of war, but diplomacy helped avoid it.”
“He was on the brink of making a major discovery when the experiment failed.”

Vocabulary/On-The-Right-Track.title: On The Right Track
Vocabulary/On-The-Right-Track.content:
on the right track
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
To be doing something in a way that will likely lead to success or a correct result.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“You’re on the right track with your approach to solving the problem.”
“If you keep practicing, you’ll be on the right track to becoming a great musician.”
“The team’s strategy in the second half shows they’re on the right track to winning the game.”
“Her hard work and dedication prove that she’s on the right track for a promotion.”
“The changes in your presentation suggest you’re on the right track to impress the clients.”

Vocabulary/Open-To-Dispute.title: Open To Dispute
Vocabulary/Open-To-Dispute.content:
open to dispute
Definition
Word Type: phrase
not certain:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


He says it’s the best musical equipment you can buy, but I think that’s open to dispute.

Vocabulary/Opposing.title: Opposing
Vocabulary/Opposing.content:
opposing
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
Being in conflict or disagreement with something; actively resisting or working against something.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The opposing team scored the final goal in the last minute of the game.”
“She held an opposing viewpoint during the debate, challenging every argument made.”
“The opposing sides of the issue could not come to an agreement.”
“They faced opposing forces in the battle, but were determined to fight for their cause.”
“The opposing candidate gave a strong speech that gained a lot of attention.”

Vocabulary/Optimist.title: Optimist
Vocabulary/Optimist.content:
optimist
Definition
Word Type: noun
someone who always believes that good things will happen:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


She’s a born optimist (= someone who has always been optimistic).

Vocabulary/Optimistic.title: Optimistic
Vocabulary/Optimistic.content:
optimistic
Definition
Word Type: adjective
hoping or believing that good things will happen in the future:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


optimistic about She is optimistic about her chances of winning a gold medal.

Vocabulary/Outlive.title: Outlive
Vocabulary/Outlive.content:
outlive
Definition
Word Type: verb
to live or exist longer than someone or something:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


He outlived all of his brothers.

Vocabulary/Output.title: Output
Vocabulary/Output.content:
output
Definition
Word Type: noun
the amount that is produced by a person, machine, factory, country, etc.:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Last year manufacturing output fell by 14 percent.

Vocabulary/Outrun.title: Outrun
Vocabulary/Outrun.content:
outrun
Word Type: verb
Definition
to move faster or further than someone or something:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The men easily outran the police officer who was chasing them.

Vocabulary/Overbearing.title: Overbearing
Vocabulary/Overbearing.content:
overbearing
Definition
Word Type: adjective
too confident and too determined to tell other people what to do, in a way that is unpleasant:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Milligan had a pompous, overbearing father.

Vocabulary/Overbearingly.title: Overbearingly
Vocabulary/Overbearingly.content:
overbearingly
Definition
Word Type: adverb
in the manner of someone who is too confident and too determined to tell other people what to do, especially in a way that is unpleasant :


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


She grew up with an overbearingly protective mother who always checked how her daughter was dressed before she left the house.

Vocabulary/Overhear.title: Overhear
Vocabulary/Overhear.content:
overhear
Definition
Word Type: verb
to hear what other people are saying without intending to and without their knowledge:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


I overheard a very funny conversation on the bus this morning.

Vocabulary/Overlook.title: Overlook
Vocabulary/Overlook.content:
overlook
Word Type: Verb
Definition

To fail to notice or consider something, either unintentionally or because of being distracted.
To look at or view something from a higher position.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She overlooked the mistake in the report before submitting it.”
“The hotel room overlooks the ocean, providing a beautiful view.”
“He overlooked the small details, which led to problems later on.”
“Don’t overlook the importance of regular exercise for your health.”
“The manager might have overlooked your request by mistake.”

Vocabulary/Overrun.title: Overrun
Vocabulary/Overrun.content:
overrun
Definition
Word Type: verb
If unwanted people or things overrun, they fill a place quickly and in large numbers:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Rebel soldiers overran the embassy last night.

Vocabulary/Oversee.title: Oversee
Vocabulary/Oversee.content:
oversee
Definition
Word Type: verb
to watch or organize a job or an activity to make certain that it is being done correctly:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


As marketing manager, her job is to oversee all the company’s advertising.

Vocabulary/Oversight.title: Oversight
Vocabulary/Oversight.content:
oversight
Definition
Word Type: noun
a mistake made because of a failure to notice something:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


They claimed it was simply (an) oversight.

Vocabulary/Oversimplify.title: Oversimplify
Vocabulary/Oversimplify.content:
oversimplify
Definition
Word Type: verb
to describe or explain something in such a simple way that it is no longer correct or true:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The TV documentary grossly oversimplified the problem.

Vocabulary/Parallel.title: Parallel
Vocabulary/Parallel.content:
parallel
Word Type: Adjective, Noun, Verb
Definition

Describing two or more things that are similar and run in the same direction, often without meeting.
A situation, event, or experience that is similar to another.
To make or be similar or equivalent to something.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The two roads run parallel to each other.”
“The challenges he faced in life had many parallels with his father’s struggles.”
“She tried to parallel her career path with her mentor’s successful journey.”
“The parallel structure in the two poems was striking.”
“The two companies’ growth patterns were very parallel over the years.”

Vocabulary/Pass-The-Torch.title: Pass The Torch
Vocabulary/Pass-The-Torch.content:
Pass the Torch
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
To give responsibility or a role to someone else, typically after one has completed or finished their task.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“After many years of leading the company, he decided to pass the torch to his successor.”
“The coach decided to pass the torch to the new captain of the team.”
“She chose to pass the torch to the younger generation, letting them lead the project.”
“The professor is ready to pass the torch to a new mentor for the next group of students.”
“He was honored to pass the torch to his apprentice, who had learned everything he could teach.”

Vocabulary/Payoff.title: Payoff
Vocabulary/Payoff.content:
payoff
Word Type: Noun
Definition

The return or result of an effort, investment, or action, often a reward or benefit.
A final outcome, especially one that is positive or successful.
(Informally) A bribe or illegal payment.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“After months of hard work, the payoff came when she received the promotion.”
“The payoff of their years of training was a gold medal at the Olympics.”
“The payoff for investing in the company was much higher than expected.”
“The payoff of this project will be significant, both financially and professionally.”
“The detectives investigated the payoff but couldn’t find any evidence of wrongdoing.”

Vocabulary/Peer.title: Peer
Vocabulary/Peer.content:
peer
Word Type: Noun, Verb
Definition

A person who is equal to another in age, social status, or ability.
To look closely or carefully at something.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She felt comfortable discussing ideas with her peers in the group.”
“The manager asked her to peer at the document to check for errors.”
“In school, he was always the peer everyone looked up to for advice.”
“They studied together, as peers in the same academic program.”
“The team members were all peers, working collaboratively on the project.”

Vocabulary/Perceive.title: Perceive
Vocabulary/Perceive.content:
perceive
Definition
Word Type: verb
to come to an opinion about something, or have a belief about something:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


How do the French perceive the British?

Vocabulary/Perception.title: Perception
Vocabulary/Perception.content:
perception
Definition
Word Type: noun
a belief or opinion, often held by many people and based on how things seem:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


We have to change the public’s perception that money is being wasted.

Vocabulary/Perceptive.title: Perceptive
Vocabulary/Perceptive.content:
perceptive
Definition
Word Type: adjective
very good at noticing and understanding things that many people do not notice:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Her books are full of perceptive insights into the human condition.

Vocabulary/Perceptively.title: Perceptively
Vocabulary/Perceptively.content:
perceptively
Definition
Word Type: adverb
in a way that shows the ability to notice and understand things that many people do not notice:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


He has spoken perceptively on many subjects.

Vocabulary/Perceptivity.title: Perceptivity
Vocabulary/Perceptivity.content:
perceptivity
Word Type:
Definition
Definition not found


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Pessimistic.title: Pessimistic
Vocabulary/Pessimistic.content:
pessimistic
Definition
Word Type: adjective
thinking that bad things are more likely to happen or emphasizing the bad part of a situation:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The tone of the meeting was very pessimistic.

Vocabulary/Photogenic.title: Photogenic
Vocabulary/Photogenic.content:
photogenic
Definition
Word Type: adjective
having a face that looks attractive in photographs


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Photographic.title: Photographic
Vocabulary/Photographic.content:
photographic
Definition
Word Type: adjective
relating to, used for, or produced by photography:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


photographic equipment/film/materials

Vocabulary/Pick-Up.title: Pick Up
Vocabulary/Pick-Up.content:
pick up
Word Type: Phrasal Verb
Definition

To lift or collect someone or something.
To learn or acquire information or a skill.
To improve or become better.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“I’ll pick you up at 7:00 for the party.”
“She went to the store to pick up some groceries.”
“He quickly picked up the new language while living abroad.”
“The company’s sales began to pick up after the new advertising campaign.”
“Can you pick up the kids from school today?”

Vocabulary/Pine.title: Pine
Vocabulary/Pine.content:
pine
Word Type: Noun, Verb
Definition

an evergreen tree (= one that never loses its leaves) that grows in cooler areas of the world:
To feel deep sorrow or longing, often for something that is lost or unattainable.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She has been pining for her hometown since she moved away.”
“He spent years pining for the lost opportunity.”
“After the breakup, he began to pine for her, unable to move on.”
“They pined for their old life before the move to the city.”
“She sat by the window, pining for a life of adventure.”

Vocabulary/Pinnacle.title: Pinnacle
Vocabulary/Pinnacle.content:
pinnacle
Word Type: Noun
Definition
The highest point or peak of something, often representing the greatest achievement or success.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“Winning the Nobel Prize was the pinnacle of his career.”
“The team’s victory in the finals marked the pinnacle of their season.”
“Climbing Mount Everest is considered the pinnacle of many mountaineers’ achievements.”
“Her performance in the play was the pinnacle of the production.”
“He reached the pinnacle of his profession after decades of hard work.”

Vocabulary/Platform-agnostic.title: Platform-agnostic
Vocabulary/Platform-agnostic.content:
platform-agnostic
Definition
Word Type:
a product or service can operate across multiple platforms, systems, or technologies without being limited to a specific one.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The app is platform-agnostic, meaning it can be used on any device or platform.

Vocabulary/Play-truant.title: Play truant
Vocabulary/Play-truant.content:
Play truant
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
To stay away from school without permission or a valid reason.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“He used to play truant from school to hang out with his friends at the arcade.”
“The teacher warned the students not to play truant during exam week.”
“When she was younger, she would sometimes play truant to avoid difficult classes.”
“The principal introduced stricter rules to reduce the number of students who play truant.”
“His parents were furious when they discovered he had been playing truant for weeks.”

Vocabulary/Ponder.title: Ponder
Vocabulary/Ponder.content:
ponder
Definition
Word Type: verb
to think carefully about something, especially for a noticeable length of time:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


She sat back for a minute to ponder her next move in the game.

Vocabulary/Ponderable.title: Ponderable
Vocabulary/Ponderable.content:
ponderable
Definition
Word Type: adjective
able to be guessed or calculated by thinking:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Professional philosophers consider these questions to be eminently ponderable.

Vocabulary/Ponderous.title: Ponderous
Vocabulary/Ponderous.content:
ponderous
Definition
Word Type: adjective
slow and awkward because of being very heavy or large:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


He had a slow and ponderous manner.

Vocabulary/Poor.title: Poor
Vocabulary/Poor.content:
poor
Definition
Word Type: adjective
having little money and/or few possessions:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Most of the world’s poorest countries are in Africa.

Vocabulary/Poorly.title: Poorly
Vocabulary/Poorly.content:
poorly
Definition
Word Type: adverb
not well:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


A business as poorly managed as that one doesn’t deserve to succeed.

Vocabulary/Poorness.title: Poorness
Vocabulary/Poorness.content:
poorness
Word Type:
Definition
Definition not found


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Possess.title: Possess
Vocabulary/Possess.content:
possess
Word Type: Verb
Definition
To have or own something; to control or have a particular quality.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She possesses great artistic talent.”
“The company possesses a vast amount of data on consumer behavior.”
“He possesses the skills necessary to lead the team.”
“They possess a beautiful collection of rare books.”
“In the fantasy story, the hero must possess the magical sword to save the kingdom.”

Vocabulary/Praise.title: Praise
Vocabulary/Praise.content:
praise
Word Type: Noun, Verb
Definition

The expression of approval or admiration for someone or something.
To express approval or admiration for someone or something.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The teacher gave her a lot of praise for completing the project ahead of schedule.”
“He was praised for his hard work and dedication during the meeting.”
“The praise from her colleagues made her feel valued and appreciated.”
“It’s important to praise children for their efforts, not just their results.”
“The coach praised the team for their sportsmanship after the game.”

Vocabulary/Precedent.title: Precedent
Vocabulary/Precedent.content:
precedent
Word Type: Noun
Definition
An earlier event or action that is regarded as an example or guide for future actions.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The court decision set a precedent for future legal cases.”
“Her success in the company created a precedent for others to follow.”
“The government action was based on a precedent established years ago.”
“The precedent for this type of behavior has not been established.”
“They looked to historical precedents to make their decision.”

Vocabulary/Precious.title: Precious
Vocabulary/Precious.content:
precious
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
Something that is highly valued or cherished, often because of its rarity, beauty, or importance.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The necklace she inherited from her grandmother is a precious family heirloom.”
“Their precious memories of childhood shaped who they became as adults.”
“He kept a precious photograph of his dog in his wallet.”
“The rare diamond was considered one of the most precious jewels in the world.”
“She treated her time with her children as precious and made every moment count.”

Vocabulary/Preposition.title: Preposition
Vocabulary/Preposition.content:
preposition
Word Type: noun
Definition
in grammar, a word that is used before a noun, a noun phrase, or a pronoun, connecting it to another word:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


In the sentences “We jumped in the lake”, and “She drove slowly down the track”, “in” and “down” are prepositions.

Vocabulary/Prerequisite.title: Prerequisite
Vocabulary/Prerequisite.content:
prerequisite
Definition
Word Type: noun
something that must exist or happen before something else can exist or happen:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Passing a written test is a prerequisite for taking the advanced course.

Vocabulary/Primal-Instincts.title: Primal Instincts
Vocabulary/Primal-Instincts.content:
primal instincts
Word Type: Noun Phrase
Definition
The basic, innate, and often subconscious behaviors or reactions that humans and animals have, typically linked to survival or reproduction.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“In dangerous situations, people often rely on their primal instincts to protect themselves.”
“The primal instincts of animals drive them to hunt, gather food, and survive in the wild.”
“Her primal instincts kicked in when she heard a baby crying in distress.”
“Humans may suppress their primal instincts in society, but they are still present.”
“During the competition, his primal instincts pushed him to run faster than ever.”

Vocabulary/Privilege.title: Privilege
Vocabulary/Privilege.content:
privilege
Word Type: Noun
Definition
A special right, advantage, or immunity granted or available only to a particular person or group.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“It was a privilege to meet the famous author in person.”
“Access to exclusive events is a privilege reserved for VIP members.”
“She considered it a privilege to work with such talented colleagues.”
“The students felt a sense of privilege being able to study at such a prestigious university.”
“In some countries, owning a car is still a privilege rather than a necessity.”

Vocabulary/Profound.title: Profound
Vocabulary/Profound.content:
profound
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
Having deep meaning, significance, or impact, often related to emotions, thoughts, or experiences.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The speech had a profound effect on the audience, leaving many in tears.”
“He gave a profound analysis of the book that changed my perspective.”
“Her profound understanding of human nature made her an excellent counselor.”
“The loss of her childhood friend had a profound impact on her life.”
“The documentary provided a profound insight into the lives of the elderly.”

Vocabulary/Proposal.title: Proposal
Vocabulary/Proposal.content:
proposal
Definition
Word Type: noun
a suggestion, sometimes a written one:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Congress has rejected the latest economic proposal put forward by the President.

Vocabulary/Provided.title: Provided
Vocabulary/Provided.content:
provided
Definition
Word Type: verb
past simple and past participle of


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Pull-Off.title: Pull Off
Vocabulary/Pull-Off.content:
pull off
Word Type: Phrasal Verb
Definition
To succeed in doing something difficult or unexpected.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She managed to pull off an incredible surprise party for her friend.”
“Against all odds, the team was able to pull off a victory in the final minutes of the game.”
“I didn’t think he could pull it off, but he finished the project on time.”
“Despite the challenges, they pulled off the event without a hitch.”
“It seemed impossible, but they pulled it off and won the competition.”

Vocabulary/Pulled-It-Off.title: Pulled It Off
Vocabulary/Pulled-It-Off.content:
pulled it off
Word Type: phrasal verb
Definition
to succeed in doing something difficult or unexpected:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The central bank has pulled off one of the biggest financial rescues of recent years.

Vocabulary/Purgatory.title: Purgatory
Vocabulary/Purgatory.content:
purgatory
Word Type: Noun
Definition
A state or place of temporary suffering, often used metaphorically to describe a period of distress or uncertainty.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“Waiting for the final decision felt like being in purgatory.”
“The long, painful recovery after the accident was a form of purgatory for him.”
“For her, the weeks leading up to the job interview were a kind of emotional purgatory.”
“The unresolved argument left their friendship in purgatory for months.”
“He described his time in the office as a daily purgatory of stress and frustration.”

Vocabulary/Put-On-A-Face.title: Put On A Face
Vocabulary/Put-On-A-Face.content:
put on a face
Definition
Word Type: idiom
to behave as if a problem is not important or does not worry you:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


She seems all right but I think she’s just putting on a brave face.

Vocabulary/Put-On-A-Strike.title: Put On A Strike
Vocabulary/Put-On-A-Strike.content:
put on a strike
Word Type:
Definition
Definition not found


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Put-Sb-On-The-Right-Track.title: Put Sb On The Right Track
Vocabulary/Put-Sb-On-The-Right-Track.content:
put sb on the right track
Word Type: Verb phrase
Definition
To guide or direct someone in the correct way or in the direction of understanding or success.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The advice from my mentor really put me on the right track in my career.

Vocabulary/Put-Up-A-Fight.title: Put Up A Fight
Vocabulary/Put-Up-A-Fight.content:
Put up a fight
Word Type: Collocation
Definition
To resist or struggle against something, often with determination or effort.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The boxer was exhausted but still managed to put up a fight in the final round.”
“They tried to evict her, but she put up a fight and refused to leave.”
“Even though they were outnumbered, the soldiers put up a fight to defend their position.”
“The company put up a fight against the lawsuit, claiming they did nothing wrong.”
“He didn’t agree with the decision, but he didn’t put up a fight and accepted it quietly.”

Vocabulary/Put-in-place.title: Put in place
Vocabulary/Put-in-place.content:
put in place
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
To establish or implement something, especially a rule, system, or structure.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“New safety measures were put in place after the accident.”
“The company has put in place a new policy to improve customer service.”
“A security team was put in place to ensure the event went smoothly.”
“The government has put in place several programs to address homelessness.”
“After the renovation, new guidelines were put in place to maintain the building.”

Vocabulary/Put.title: Put
Vocabulary/Put.content:
put
Definition
Word Type: verb
to move something or someone into the stated place, position, or direction:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Where have you put the keys?

Vocabulary/Quarrel.title: Quarrel
Vocabulary/Quarrel.content:
quarrel
Definition
Word Type: noun
an angry disagreement between two or more people or groups:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


They had a bitter quarrel about/over some money three years ago and they haven’t spoken to each other since.

Vocabulary/Quench.title: Quench
Vocabulary/Quench.content:
quench
Word Type: Verb
Definition

To satisfy thirst by drinking.
To put out a fire or extinguish.
To stop or reduce something, such as a feeling or desire.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She drank a cold glass of water to quench her thirst after the long hike.”
“Firefighters worked quickly to quench the blaze before it spread.”
“The news did little to quench his excitement about the upcoming trip.”
“Nothing could quench his desire to succeed in the field of technology.”
“The rain helped quench the dry soil in the garden.”

Vocabulary/Read-Between-The-Lines.title: Read Between The Lines
Vocabulary/Read-Between-The-Lines.content:
read between the lines
Definition
Word Type: idiom
to try to understand someone’s real feelings or intentions from what they say or write:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Reading between the lines, I’d say he isn’t happy with the situation.

Vocabulary/Realization.title: Realization
Vocabulary/Realization.content:
realization
Word Type: Noun
Definition
The act of becoming aware of something or achieving a clear understanding of it; the fulfillment or achievement of something hoped for or desired.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The realization that she had won the prize took a moment to sink in.”
“After hours of study, he had a sudden realization about how to solve the problem.”
“Her realization that she needed to change her career path came after years of dissatisfaction.”
“The realization of their dream home was something they’d been working towards for years.”
“He had a realization that success was not about wealth, but about personal growth.”

Vocabulary/Reasonable.title: Reasonable
Vocabulary/Reasonable.content:
reasonable
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
Fair, sensible, or within the limits of what is practical or acceptable.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The price for the car seems reasonable, given its age and condition.”
“She made a reasonable suggestion to improve the project’s outcome.”
“The teacher gave a reasonable amount of homework for the weekend.”
“It’s reasonable to expect a response within 24 hours.”
“The restaurant’s portions were reasonable for the price.”

Vocabulary/Recognition.title: Recognition
Vocabulary/Recognition.content:
recognition
Word Type: Noun
Definition
The act of acknowledging or identifying someone or something, often with approval or respect.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She received recognition for her outstanding performance in the company.”
“The artist gained recognition after her work was displayed in a major gallery.”
“His efforts went unnoticed, but the team later gave him recognition for his hard work.”
“The award was a well-deserved recognition of his years of dedication.”
“He didn’t seek recognition; he just wanted to help others.”

Vocabulary/Recount.title: Recount
Vocabulary/Recount.content:
recount
Word Type: Verb, Noun
Definition

To tell someone a story or describe something in detail, especially something that has happened.
A detailed or complete account of an event or experience.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Verb: “She was asked to recount her experience during the interview.”
Verb: “He recounted the events of the trip with great enthusiasm.”
Noun: “The book is a recount of the author’s travels around the world.”
Noun: “The recount of the election results showed a close race.”

Vocabulary/Redeem.title: Redeem
Vocabulary/Redeem.content:
redeem
Definition
Word Type: verb
to make something or someone seem less bad:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


A poor game was redeemed in the second half by a superb performance from Anthony Edwards.

Vocabulary/Reference.title: Reference
Vocabulary/Reference.content:
reference
Definition
Word Type: noun
a mention of something:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Knowing what had happened, I avoided making any reference to (= mentioning) weddings.

Vocabulary/Refine.title: Refine
Vocabulary/Refine.content:
refine
Word Type: Verb
Definition
To improve something by making small changes, or to make something more elegant or cultured.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She decided to refine her presentation to make it more engaging.”
“The company is working to refine its production process to be more efficient.”
“Over the years, he has refined his skills in painting.”
“The chef will refine the recipe to create a more sophisticated flavor.”
“His writing has been refined through years of practice and feedback.”

Vocabulary/Reflect.title: Reflect
Vocabulary/Reflect.content:
reflect
Definition
Word Type: verb
If a surface reflects light, heat, sound, or an image, it sends the light, etc. back and does not absorb it:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


He saw himself reflected in the water/mirror/shop window.

Vocabulary/Reflection.title: Reflection
Vocabulary/Reflection.content:
reflection
Word Type: Noun
Definition

The image of something in a mirror, on a shiny surface, or in water.
Serious thought or consideration.
An indication or expression of something.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She admired her reflection in the mirror before leaving for the party.”
“After the meeting, he spent some time in quiet reflection about the decisions made.”
“His behavior is a reflection of his strong upbringing.”
“The reflection of the mountains in the lake was breathtaking.”
“The book encourages self-reflection to help readers understand their emotions better.”

Vocabulary/Reflective.title: Reflective
Vocabulary/Reflective.content:
reflective
Word Type: adjective
Definition
A reflective surface sends back most of the light that shines on it and can therefore be seen easily.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


After hearing the news they sat in a quiet, reflective silence.

Vocabulary/Regime.title: Regime
Vocabulary/Regime.content:
regime
Word Type: Noun
Definition
A system or planned way of doing things, especially one imposed by a government, organization, or authority.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The country was under a strict military regime after the coup.”
“The new fitness regime helped her achieve her health goals.”
“The political regime in power was criticized for its lack of freedoms.”
“The hospital has a new nutrition regime for patients recovering from surgery.”
“The country’s regime was known for its harsh policies towards opposition.”

Vocabulary/Regulation.title: Regulation
Vocabulary/Regulation.content:
regulation
Word Type: Noun
Definition
A rule or directive made and maintained by an authority, often to manage or control specific activities or behavior.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The company must comply with government regulations regarding safety standards.”
“There are new regulations on how businesses must handle customer data.”
“Environmental regulations are becoming stricter to combat climate change.”
“The university has regulations to ensure fairness during exams.”
“The bank must follow financial regulations set by the central authority.”

Vocabulary/Reinterpret.title: Reinterpret
Vocabulary/Reinterpret.content:
reinterpret
Definition
Word Type: verb
to change what you think the meaning of something is:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The technique trains patients to reinterpret a traumatic event from a different perspective.

Vocabulary/Relive.title: Relive
Vocabulary/Relive.content:
relive
Definition
Word Type: verb
to remember clearly an experience that happened in the past:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Whenever I smell burning, I relive the final moments of the crash.

Vocabulary/Rerun.title: Rerun
Vocabulary/Rerun.content:
rerun
Word Type: verb
Definition
to show a television programme, film, etc. again:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The James Bond movies are always being rerun on television.

Vocabulary/Reseal.title: Reseal
Vocabulary/Reseal.content:
reseal
Definition
Word Type: verb
to close an envelope or container again by sticking the edges together:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The cigarette packet had been opened and re-sealed with sticky tape.

Vocabulary/Resort-To.title: Resort To
Vocabulary/Resort-To.content:
resort to
Definition
Word Type: phrasal verb
to do something that you do not want to do because you cannot find any other way of achieving something:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


I had to resort to violence/threats to get my money.

Vocabulary/Retrain.title: Retrain
Vocabulary/Retrain.content:
retrain
Definition
Word Type: verb
to learn new skills so you can do a different job:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Mark used to be an actor but now he’s retraining as a teacher.

Vocabulary/Rhetorical-Question.title: Rhetorical Question
Vocabulary/Rhetorical-Question.content:
rhetorical question
Word Type: Noun
Definition
A question asked for effect or to make a point, rather than to receive an answer.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“When he asked, ‘Who doesn’t want to be successful?’ it was a rhetorical question.”
“Her rhetorical question about the importance of honesty made everyone reflect on their actions.”
“The teacher used a rhetorical question to emphasize the need for hard work.”
“During the speech, the politician asked several rhetorical questions to stir the crowd’s emotions.”
“He raised a rhetorical question about the fairness of the decision, leaving no room for debate.”

Vocabulary/Rhetorical-Questions.title: Rhetorical Questions
Vocabulary/Rhetorical-Questions.content:
rhetorical question
Word Type: Noun
Definition
A question asked for effect or to make a point, rather than to receive an answer.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“When he asked, ‘Who doesn’t want to be successful?’ it was a rhetorical question.”
“Her rhetorical question about the importance of honesty made everyone reflect on their actions.”
“The teacher used a rhetorical question to emphasize the need for hard work.”
“During the speech, the politician asked several rhetorical questions to stir the crowd’s emotions.”
“He raised a rhetorical question about the fairness of the decision, leaving no room for debate.”

Vocabulary/Rich.title: Rich
Vocabulary/Rich.content:
rich
Definition
Word Type: adjective
having a lot of money or valuable possessions:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


He’s the third richest man in the country.

Vocabulary/Richly.title: Richly
Vocabulary/Richly.content:
richly
Definition
Word Type: adverb
having a lot of beautiful or expensive decoration, furniture, etc.:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The façade of the church is richly decorated in green and white marble.

Vocabulary/Richness.title: Richness
Vocabulary/Richness.content:
richness
Definition
Word Type: noun
the quality of having a lot of something that is valuable or interesting:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


We were impressed by the great richness of detail in her painting.

Vocabulary/Risk-averse.title: Risk-averse
Vocabulary/Risk-averse.content:
risk-averse
Definition
Word Type: adjective
unwilling to take risks or wanting to avoid risks as much as possible:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


He feels modern attitudes to children’s play are too restrictive and risk-averse.

Vocabulary/Role-Model.title: Role Model
Vocabulary/Role-Model.content:
role model
Word Type: Noun
Definition
A person who is admired and looked up to for their behavior, achievements, or qualities, often serving as an example for others to follow.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She has always been a great role model for her younger sister.”
“Many athletes are seen as role models by young fans.”
“The teacher was a role model for her students, demonstrating hard work and kindness.”
“As a community leader, he became a role model for many aspiring activists.”
“Her honesty and dedication made her a role model in the workplace.”

Vocabulary/Roleplay.title: Roleplay
Vocabulary/Roleplay.content:
roleplay
Word Type: Noun, Verb
Definition

A practice activity where people act out roles to explore situations, often for training or learning purposes.
To act out a role in a specific scenario, often for educational or training purposes.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“In the workshop, participants will role-play different customer service scenarios.”
“The teacher asked the students to role-play as historical figures to better understand the events.”
“Their role-play exercise helped them practice handling difficult conversations.”
“She enjoys role-playing various characters to improve her acting skills.”
“The role-play helped the team improve their communication in stressful situations.”

Vocabulary/Room-For-Improvement.title: Room For Improvement
Vocabulary/Room-For-Improvement.content:
room for improvement
Definition
Word Type: idiom
a possibility or hope that someone or something will improve.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Her writing is better but there is still room for improvement.

Vocabulary/Run-Out-Of-Sth.title: Run Out Of Sth
Vocabulary/Run-Out-Of-Sth.content:
run out of sth
Definition
Word Type:
to use up all of something:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The company ran out of money last month.

Vocabulary/Run.title: Run
Vocabulary/Run.content:
run
Definition
Word Type: verb
(of people and some animals) to move along, faster than walking, by taking quick steps in which each foot is lifted before the next foot touches the ground:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


[ + to infinitive ] The children had to run to keep up with their father.

Vocabulary/Runic.title: Runic
Vocabulary/Runic.content:
runic
Word Type: adjective
Definition
relating to runes (= magic marks or letters, especially the letters of an ancient alphabet cut into stone or wood in the past):


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


a runic letter/alphabet/message

Vocabulary/Runner.title: Runner
Vocabulary/Runner.content:
runner
Definition
Word Type: noun
someone who runs, especially in competitions:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


a long-distance runner

Vocabulary/Sanguine.title: Sanguine
Vocabulary/Sanguine.content:
sanguine
Definition
Word Type: adjective
(of someone or someone’s character) positive and hoping for good things:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


They are less sanguine about the prospects for peace.

Vocabulary/Screw-it.title: Screw it
Vocabulary/Screw-it.content:
Screw it
Word Type: Phrase
Definition
A phrase used to express a decision to stop worrying about something and to take action, often because of frustration or lack of desire to continue.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“I don’t feel like doing this anymore—screw it, I’m going home.”
“I was going to try and finish the project, but screw it, I’ll start over tomorrow.”
“We couldn’t figure it out after hours of trying, so we just said, ‘screw it,’ and left.”
“I’m tired of waiting for things to change, screw it, I’m moving forward with my plans.”
“The weather is bad, but screw it, I’m going to the beach anyway.”

Vocabulary/Scribble.title: Scribble
Vocabulary/Scribble.content:
scribble
Word Type: verb
Definition
to write or draw something quickly or carelessly:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The baby’s just scribbled all over my new dictionary!

Vocabulary/Seal.title: Seal
Vocabulary/Seal.content:
seal
Definition
Word Type: noun
a large mammal that eats fish and lives partly in the sea and partly on land or ice


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Clean the seal on/around the fridge door regularly so that it remains airtight.

Vocabulary/Seance.title: Seance
Vocabulary/Seance.content:
seance
Definition
Word Type: noun
a meeting where people try to talk with dead people:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


They’re holding a séance this evening.

Vocabulary/Secretary.title: Secretary
Vocabulary/Secretary.content:
secretary
Word Type: Noun
Definition
A person employed to handle correspondence, keep records, and perform other administrative tasks.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“She works as a secretary at a law firm, handling all the scheduling and paperwork.”
“The secretary of the board took detailed notes during the meeting.”
“He hired a secretary to manage his calendar and correspondence.”
“As a secretary, she was responsible for organizing the office and filing documents.”
“The company’s secretary coordinated communication between the CEO and staff.”

Vocabulary/See-To-It.title: See To It
Vocabulary/See-To-It.content:
see to it
Definition
Word Type: phrasal verb
to deal with a person or task that needs to be dealt with or is waiting to be dealt with:


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/See.title: See
Vocabulary/See.content:
see
Definition
Word Type: verb
to be conscious of what is around you by using your eyes:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Turn the light on so I can see.

Vocabulary/Seemingly.title: Seemingly
Vocabulary/Seemingly.content:
seemingly
Word Type: Adverb
Definition
In a way that appears to be true based on what is visible or apparent, but may not necessarily be the case.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“The solution to the problem seemed seemingly simple, but it took much longer to fix.”
“He was seemingly happy, but deep down, he was struggling.”
“The team’s success was seemingly effortless, but they had worked hard behind the scenes.”
“She gave a seemingly innocent response, but I could tell she was hiding something.”
“The mountain trail was seemingly easy, but it turned out to be much more difficult than we expected.”

Vocabulary/Self-Awareness.title: Self-Awareness
Vocabulary/Self-Awareness.content:
self-awareness
Word Type: Noun
Definition
The ability to recognize and understand one’s own emotions, behaviors, and thoughts, and how they affect others.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“Developing self-awareness is key to improving emotional intelligence.”
“Through meditation, she gained a deeper sense of self-awareness.”
“His self-awareness helped him manage his reactions in stressful situations.”
“With more self-awareness, she was able to improve her relationships with others.”
“The leadership workshop focused on enhancing self-awareness among managers.”

Vocabulary/Shame.title: Shame
Vocabulary/Shame.content:
shame
Definition
Word Type: noun
If something is described as a shame, it is disappointing or not satisfactory:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


[ + that ] It’s a (great/real) shame that the event had to be cancelled.

Vocabulary/Show.title: Show
Vocabulary/Show.content:
show
Definition
Word Type: verb
to make it possible for something to be seen:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


[ + two objects ] Let me show you this new book I’ve just bought.

Vocabulary/Showy.title: Showy
Vocabulary/Showy.content:
showy
Definition
Word Type: adjective
attracting a lot of attention by being very colourful or bright, but without any real beauty:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


a showy production of a play

Vocabulary/Shrink.title: Shrink
Vocabulary/Shrink.content:
shrink
Definition
Word Type: verb
to become smaller, or to make something smaller:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Your sweater will shrink if you wash it at too high a temperature.

Vocabulary/Shrinkable.title: Shrinkable
Vocabulary/Shrinkable.content:
shrinkable
Word Type:
Definition
Definition not found


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Shrinkage.title: Shrinkage
Vocabulary/Shrinkage.content:
shrinkage
Definition
Word Type: noun
a reduction in the size of something, or the process of becoming smaller:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Synthetic fabrics are less susceptible to shrinkage than natural ones.

Vocabulary/Sight.title: Sight
Vocabulary/Sight.content:
sight
Definition
Word Type: noun
the ability to see:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


If your sight is poor, you should not drive a car.

Vocabulary/Sightless.title: Sightless
Vocabulary/Sightless.content:
sightless
Definition
Word Type: adjective
unable to see


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Sightly.title: Sightly
Vocabulary/Sightly.content:
sightly
Definition
Word Type: adjective
attractive or pleasing to look at or see:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Plastic polytunnels aren’t the sightliest of agricultural buildings.

Vocabulary/Silly.title: Silly
Vocabulary/Silly.content:
silly
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
Having or showing a lack of common sense or judgment; foolish or unreasonable.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


“It was silly of me to forget her birthday.”
“The movie was full of silly jokes and exaggerated characters.”
“He made a silly mistake by not double-checking his work.”
“Don’t be silly; you know you’re capable of doing this task.”
“They were laughing at silly things during the meeting, which distracted everyone.”

Vocabulary/Simple.title: Simple
Vocabulary/Simple.content:
simple
Definition
